content.fullTitle: Wax and Tallow: Material Explorations
content.name: Wax and Tallow
content.citeAs: Cataldo, Emogene, and Julianna van Visco. “Wax and Tallow: Material Explorations.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_001_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/0cp6-7h54
content.abstract: Wax and tallow are easily transformed from solid to liquid and back again. Their properties, such as hardness, opacity, malleability, and carvability, can also be transformed through the addition of various substances, including resins, earths, and pigments. These versatile materials were used for many purposes in early modern Europe, and also possessed a range of symbolic, sacramental, and other cultural meanings. Taking inspiration from the entry on fol. 109r for “Modeling in wax,” this essay provides a preliminary exploration of the broad uses and meanings of these important materials.

content.fullTitle: Molding Hollow on One Side and in Relief on the Other
content.name: Molding Hollow on One Side and in Relief on the Other
content.citeAs: Landsman, Rozemarijn, and Jonah Rowen. “Molding Hollow on One Side and in Relief on the Other.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_002_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/spcq-m286
content.abstract: This essay explains and reconstructs the method of casting medals as described on fols. 83v and 92r. This type of medal, which is cast with a convex relief on the obverse and an exact concave negative of the relief on the reverse, was widespread throughout Europe by the late sixteenth century. Modern scholars frequently refer to these medals as “without reverse,” “hollow cast,” “incuse-reverse cast,” or “uniface.” Little is known about the methods of their production. Ms. Fr. 640 presents at least one entry describing a previously unknown method for casting this type of medal. This essay sheds new light on their facture, and discusses their broader significance within Ms. Fr. 640 and in other contemporary sources.

content.fullTitle: Molded Roses in Sixteenth-Century France
content.name: Molded Roses
content.citeAs: Carlson, Raymond, and Jordan Katz. “Molded Roses in Sixteenth-Century France.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_003_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/t9dt-5p13
content.abstract: Three entries in Ms. Fr. 640—on fols. 129r, 155r, 155v—are devoted exclusively to molding and casting roses. This essay clarifies some of the differences between the recipes, and suggests a potential change recorded by the author-practitioner that may have resulted from repeated experiments with the techniques over time. This set of entries are related to the molding and casting of other “thin things,” such as flies' wings, another thin, delicate substance that, like rose petals, necessitated separate castings. This essay proposes that the motives for singling out roses as an object to be molded are likely related to sixteenth-century literary culture in France, perhaps especially in Toulouse, where a literary society known in the sixteenth century as the College de l’Art et Science de Rhétorique awarded cast flowers as prizes for an annual poetry contest, the Jeux Floraux, which originated in the city in the fourteenth century.

content.fullTitle: Creating Original Patterns for Casting in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Creating Original Patterns for Casting in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Landsman, Rozemarijn, and Jonah Rowen. “Creating Original Patterns for Casting in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_004_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/hbnz-5z03
content.abstract: Despite the quantity, detail, and breadth of entries about metalworking in Ms. Fr. 640, most instructions for casting presume that the object to be cast—usually medals, animals, or plants—already exists. The entries thus very rarely address the fabrication of the original pattern for making the mold. Medals are frequently reproduced or made in serial production in Ms. Fr. 640, but the actual procedure for making that first model is left mostly unmentioned. This essay investigates the few instances in the manuscript for creating patterns, including fols. 50r and 156r, and compares them to other sixteenth-century sources that treat molding and casting.

content.fullTitle: Molding Paper with Raised Letters
content.name: Molding Paper with Raised Letters
content.citeAs: Carlson, Raymond, Jordan Katz, and Baris Gokturk. “Molding Paper with Raised Letters.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_005_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/sb3y-cs42
content.abstract: “Letters and molded paper” on fol. 131r of BnF Ms. Fr. 640 describes how to lay thick ink on paper, apply eau-de-vie, mold it, then cast it in metal. The purpose of “lifecast” paper with writing was not clear to the first cohort of students who reconstructed this procedure, however, over the course of two subsequent reconstructions of molding paper with raised letters, students gained further insight into this brief entry. These reconstructions considered and experimented with various materials in the entry, and compared this entry to others in the manuscript that show the author-practitioner’s concern with practical techniques for casting thin, delicate things, such as insect wings.

content.fullTitle: Try Burnt Oysters: Deciphering Marginalia
content.name: Try Burnt Oysters
content.citeAs: Cataldo, Emogene, and Julianna van Visco. “Try Burnt Oysters: Deciphering Marginalia." In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_006_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/3ycw-r465
content.abstract: In an attempt to decipher a puzzling marginal note, “Try burnt oysters,” on fol. 84v, hands-on reconstruction in the laboratory, paired with textual research and analysis, opened several avenues for exploration. Our findings suggest that the author-practitioner knew or speculated about promising properties of oyster shells for making sand molds, but had yet to perfect a procedure for their successful use. In contrast to other more confidently phrased imperatives, such as in “Casting in frames” on fol. 118v, in which the author-practitioner writes in the first person, on fol. 84v he offers no tips, warnings, or reminders that would suggest a hands-on familiarity with the processes.

content.fullTitle: Uses of Sulfur for Casting
content.name: Uses of Sulfur for Casting
content.citeAs: Landsman, Rozemarijn, and Jonah Rowen. “Uses of Sulfur for Casting.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_007_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/tnqz-jt13
content.abstract: This essay investigates the significance of sulfur in Ms. Fr. 640, by exploring contemporary artisanal writings and by reconstructing the process of casting in sulfur and wax, using different additives found on fols. 12r and 140v. While casting in sulfur may seem unusual to modern eyes, our experiments show that sulfur, especially in combination with additives such as soot black and “sanguine,” yields results which live up to the author-practitioner’s emphasis on hard, long-lasting and detail-rich casts. Furthermore, they shed light on the author-practitioner’s preoccupation with bubble-like impurities forming in the cast. While Ms. Fr. 640 contains no theorizing about sulfur as alchemical prime matter, we suggest that the material was a metaphor for the process of experimentation itself.

content.fullTitle: Excellent Mustard
content.name: Excellent Mustard
content.citeAs: Mellon, Diana. “Excellent Mustard.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_008_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/bsgd-w246
content.abstract: The recipe for an “excellent mustard” on fol. 48r appears to produce a condiment destined directly for the table. By contrast, most other entries in the manuscript that concern foodstuffs—a relatively small group—give instructions for the cultivation and preservation of fruits and other perishables. Contemporary authors often stressed the hot and drying effects of mustards, and the particular additives used in the author-practitioner’s mustard recipe, namely cinnamon and cloves, were also understood to have such effects. This suggests that the recipe for an “excellent mustard” may relate to the various practical medical recipes peppered throughout the manuscript.

content.fullTitle: Lean Sands and Fat Binders
content.name: Lean Sands and Fat Binders
content.citeAs: Lee, Michelle, and Pamela H. Smith. “Lean Sands and Fat Binders.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_009_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/7wz5-b705
content.abstract: The entry for “Eau magistra” on fol. 84r provides instructions to produce a liquid binder to be mixed with a dry powder for the making of sand molds. Recipes for “Eau magistra” and recipes that mention magistra in BnF Ms. Fr. 640 contain many different ingredients, including elm root, vinegar, salt water, glair of egg, and “good, pure wine.” It is not clear why some binder recipes in Ms. Fr. 640 are titled magistra while other binders, seemingly identical to them in function, are not denoted as such. The dry material, or “sand,” is sometimes described as “dry and lean,” thus requiring a wet or sometimes “fatty” substance to bind it together. This essay reconstructs the entry on fol. 84r, and discusses the framework within which these qualitative binary categories of fat and lean can be understood.

content.fullTitle: Casting in Frames
content.name: Casting in Frames
content.citeAs: Carlson, Raymond, and Jordan Katz. “Casting in Frames.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_010_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/jnkw-sa96
content.abstract: The making of portrait medals and the proliferation of “books of secrets” in sixteenth-century Europe form an important historical context for “Casting in frames” on fol. 118v. This entry contains detailed instructions for making “sand” for molding and casting a portrait medal. This essay reconstructs the making and casting of a sand mold (with productive failures), and compares Ms. Fr. 640 to contemporaneous texts containing similar techniques, such as Vannoccio Biringuccio's Pirotechnia (1540) and the Secreti del Reverendo Donno Alessio Piemontese (first printed 1555).

content.fullTitle: Eau Magistra: Investigating Binders for Sand Molds
content.name: Eau Magistra
content.citeAs: Cataldo, Emogene, and Julianna van Visco. “Eau Magistra: Investigating Binders for Sand Molds.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_011_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/wzmr-ja89
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 contains a large number of recipes for and reports about various mixtures of sands and binders in making sand molds. This essay examines and reconstructs the “Eau magistra” (fols. 84v and 87v) made from elm roots boiled in wine. Its efficacy in facilitating a fine impression in a sand mold and in receiving and withstanding the molten metals was then tested and compared to other binding agents found in Ms. Fr. 640. The meaning of “magistra” as a substance that can transform the state of materials is discussed.

content.fullTitle: Fat, Lean, Sweet, Sour: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt
content.name: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt
content.citeAs: Wang, Yijun, and Pamela H. Smith. “Fat, Lean, Sweet, Sour: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_012_fa_14. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/pd1f-mt84
content.abstract: One of many recipes in BnF Ms. Fr. 640 devoted to making sand molds for metal casting, “Sand of burnt ox bones and rock salt” on fol. 89r contains only two components: “burnt ox bone” and rock salt. Most sand mold recipes contain a dry and a wet component, but this one specifies two dry components. This essay discusses sands and binders, solves the puzzle of how two dry molding components create a successful bond in the sand, and concludes by discussing the experiential and conceptual categories of fat and lean in the author-practitioner’s material imaginary.

content.fullTitle: Molding Grasshoppers and Things Too Thin
content.name: Molding Grasshoppers
content.citeAs: Fu, Shiye, Zhiqi Zhang, and Pamela H. Smith. “Molding Grasshoppers and Things Too Thin.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_013_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/fdjv-n162
content.abstract: The entry “Molding grasshoppers and things too thin” on fol. 142v describes one of the many processes of molding and casting in Ms. Fr. 640 that range from large, heavy weapons such as cannons, to small, delicate objects like flowers, insects, and even paper. This essay focuses on our close reading and hands-on reconstruction of casting “things too thin,” specifically, paper, pansies, and butterflies. We consider the properties of the various materials with which the author-practitioner experimented in order to add thickness to and strengthen delicate elements of these thin things. We also reflect on our own experience of learning to work with these materials according to their own dynamic characteristics.

content.fullTitle: Founders of Small Tin Works
content.name: Founders of Small Tin Works
content.citeAs: Chiostrini, Giulia, and Jef Palframan. “Founders of Small Tin Works.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_014_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/r4db-1352
content.abstract: “Founders of small works of tin” on fol. 80v contains a detailed description of the technique for making a stone mold and casting metal into it. This entry gives insight into a technique likely used for producing pilgrim badges that is not treated in other contemporary written sources. This essay recounts the reconstruction of this process, and it speculates on how and why the author-practitioner engaged with the practice.

content.fullTitle: Counterfeit Coral
content.name: Counterfeit Coral
content.citeAs: Chessa, Maria Alessandra. “Counterfeit Coral.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_015_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/3mtj-rk54
content.abstract: For millennia, coral has aroused the interest of natural philosophers, literary authors, and artisans who strove to imitate it. This essay argues that procedures to counterfeit coral such as the one on fol. 3r shed light on early modern understandings of the workings of nature and the relationship between nature and art.

content.fullTitle: Excellent Sand from Alabaster
content.name: Excellent Sand from Alabaster
content.citeAs: Gans, Sofia. “Excellent Sand from Alabaster.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_016_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/294x-nk86
content.abstract: The search for an “excellent” molding sand preoccupied the author-practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640. Fol. 83r contains an entry for an “Excellent sand” made with calcined alabaster powder. This essay examines why the author-practitioner might have believed that alabaster would make an excellent mold material.

content.fullTitle: Molding Fruits and Animals in Sugar
content.name: Molding Fruits and Animals in Sugar
content.citeAs: Durkin, Celia, and Pamela H. Smith. “Molding Fruits and Animals in Sugar.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_017_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/sc91-ay82
content.abstract: A single recipe in Ms. Fr. 640, on fol. 126r, gives instructions for making sugar casts of fresh fruits. Such cast sugar sculpture was a common sight at lavish banquets held in sixteenth-century European courts and cities. The author-practitioner provides practical instruction and tips for making this delicacy, but also frames his instructions within a set of properties that sugar exhibits as it changes from solid to liquid and back to solid. According to the author-practitioner, in its nature, sugar is by turns fatty, brittle, and sour. This essay explains the meaning of these properties within the author-practitioner’s material imaginary, and our reconstruction clarifies how this material imaginary provided a coherent supporting framework for the practical actions described in the recipe.

content.fullTitle: Circulation of Knowledge in Europe
content.name: Circulation of Knowledge in Europe
content.citeAs: Gans, Sofia. “Circulation of Knowledge in Europe.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_018_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/6zzw-s813
content.abstract: Several comments in Ms. Fr. 640, including on fol. 128v, show that the author-practitioner held techniques of metalworking practiced by Germans in high esteem, and he provided detailed information about practices and materials in the German lands. This essay investigates how such knowledge could have reached the author-practitioner.

content.fullTitle: Varnish for Lutes
content.name: Varnish for Lutes
content.citeAs: Marris, Caroline. “Varnish for Lutes.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_019_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/zd0f-yv91
content.abstract: Among the several entries devoted to varnish in Ms. Fr. 640, the one on fol. 98r is exclusively about varnish for lutes. Yet what makes for the specificity of this varnish? What is the purpose of its distinctively red color? By reconstructing the recipe “Varnish for lutes,” this essay examines the properties and the meaning of varnish for stringed instruments.

content.fullTitle: Sand Molds of Ox Bone, Wine, and Elm Root
content.name: Sand Molds of Ox Bone, Wine, and Elm Root
content.citeAs: Marris, Caroline, and Stephanie Pope. “Sand Molds of Ox Bone, Wine, and Elm Root.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_020_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/sz36-aj97
content.abstract: BnF Ms. Fr. 640 features several recipes for making “sand” molds. They usually involve the combination of a dry element with a wet binding agent, often referred to as “magistra.” This essay examines the sand casting technique described on fol. 84v that involves the use of a mixture of calcined and pulverized ox foot bone with elm root boiled in wine. While ox foot bone is referenced in the manuscript as an ideal medium for sand casting, the particular properties of elm root boiled in wine as a binder are less clear. In our reconstruction of the recipe entitled “Sand,” we sought not only to shed light on the ingredients and procedures involved in the preparation of the elm root and wine binder but also to consider the nature and processes by which knowledge is produced in the Making and Knowing laboratory.

content.fullTitle: Powder for Hourglasses
content.name: Powder for Hourglasses
content.citeAs: Pope, Stephanie. “Powder for Hourglasses.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_021_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/kje3-xa60
content.abstract: The hourglass had symbolic valences in early modern culture which, in the historiography, have often eclipsed its practical aspects, such as those involved in creating “powder for hourglasses” from lead and salt as described on fol. 10r of Ms. Fr. 640. This essay situates the entry among other medieval and early modern recipes for hourglass powder, which make use of a variety of ingredients (including pulverized eggshells, coral, and marble “grease”) and appear in texts ranging from fourteenth-century marital instructions to an eighteenth-century guide to maritime navigation. The entry in Ms. Fr. 640 sheds light on the fluidity between domestic and urban space in early modern Europe, the frugal and experimental quality of the domestic setting in this period, and even the material referents of certain metaphors in early modern religious writing.

content.fullTitle: Molding a Rose
content.name: Molding a Rose
content.citeAs: Chiostrini, Giulia, and Jef Palframan. “Molding a Rose.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_022_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/17zd-7y45
content.abstract: Of the many entries in Ms. Fr. 640 that contain instructions and observations on the lifecasting of plants and animals, those on fols. 155r-v deal with molding and casting a rose. Like other lifecasting entries, these appear to be a record of the author-practitioner’s first-hand experience, perhaps even evidence that he was learning as he experimented with various plants. This essay follows the author-practitioner’s instructions for molding and casting a rose, an endeavor that required close and repeated reading and trying of many of the manuscript’s other entries on the lifecasting of plants and animals.

content.fullTitle: Making Millet Bread
content.name: Making Millet Bread
content.citeAs: Chiostrini, Giulia, and Jef Palframan. “Making Millet Bread.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_023_sp_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/23kk-y750
content.abstract: The entry “For Making Millas” (fol. 20r) describes how to make millas, a type of millet bread, and bake it using terracotta molds. The purpose of our historical recipe reconstruction is to investigate the original identity of the dish millas in relation to the background of the anonymous author-practitioner, and to analyze the recipe alongside relevant contemporary and modern sources.

content.fullTitle: Painting in Oil on Taffeta I
content.name: Painting in Oil on Taffeta I
content.citeAs: Bowen, Marilyn, and Tianhe Lou. “Painting in Oil on Taffeta I.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_024_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/adp7-8568
content.abstract: This essay investigates the entry “Painting in oil on taffeta” on fol. 42v, a short recipe for a coating that can be applied to taffeta to prepare it to receive oil paint. In aim, the recipe is similar to a more detailed set of instructions on fol. 10v for making a priming coat to prevent oil paint from “running” or bleeding when painted on taffeta; however, the recipe on fol. 42v differs in materials and technique. As the recipe offers no quantities or proportions for the three ingredients, the essay questions whether this information was unknown to the author-practitioner, a workshop secret, or an implicit acknowledgement that quantities might need to be adjusted by trial and error to accommodate different pigments and oil binders.

content.fullTitle: Painting in Oil on Taffeta Without the Oil Running
content.name: Painting in Oil on Taffeta Without the Oil Running
content.citeAs: Bowen, Marilyn, and Tianhe Lou. “Painting in Oil on Taffeta Without the Oil Running.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_025_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/y0cv-7p82
content.abstract: A recipe on fol. 10v, “For painting in oil on taffeta without the oil running,” advises using batture, a vaguely described priming material, to mitigate the halo-like spread of oil from its pigment when applying oil paint to taffeta. This essay investigates the efficacy of batture, a mixture of strong glue, water, and honey, as well as the role of its various components. Artisanal recipes and our reconstruction experiments suggest that the honey functions to “soften” (adoulcir) the taffeta, that is, allow the primed taffeta to dry flat rather than crease and curl under the effect of the strong glue in the batture. This recipe belongs among those entries in Ms. Fr. 640 that attest to the author-practitioner’s interest in ornamenting fabric and in the production of ephemeral works meant for short-lived, all-weather use, such as banners and pennants.

content.fullTitle: Paintbrushes in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Paintbrushes in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Carr, Danielle. “Paintbrushes in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_026_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/m26t-hn31
content.abstract: “Paintbrushes” (“Pinceaulx”) on fols. 66v–67r is one of the few entries in Ms. Fr. 640 that concerns itself with the making of craft tools. By the sixteenth century, paintbrushes (also known as “pencils”) could be purchased ready-made by specialist artisans. Yet technical manuals and treatises on the art of painting continued to include instructions to make them in the workshop. By reconstructing the recipe and situating it in relation to contemporary recipes for brush making, this essay concludes that the level of detail and ready-to-hand materials in “Paintbrushes” suggests the author-practitioner at least witnessed brush making and perhaps even attempted it himself.

content.fullTitle: Reverse Painting on Glass
content.name: Reverse Painting on Glass
content.citeAs: Zhao, Wenrui. “Reverse Painting on Glass.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_027_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/m1ke-kd05
content.abstract: In an entry on fol. 39v titled “For tracing some history on glass,” the author-practitioner describes a technique now known as verre églomisé that imitates basse-taille enamelling. This essay examines the reemergence of this ancient technique in early modern Italy and France, and it draws on early modern objects and technical manuals to how early modern artisans understood the tasks of the painter and the goldsmith as overlapping fields of artistic production with particular shared techniques, materials, and concerns for optical effect.

content.fullTitle: Jasper Imitation on Horn
content.name: Jasper Imitation on Horn
content.citeAs: Estrades, Ana. “Jasper Imitation on Horn.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_028_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/jv1e-zr84
content.abstract: “Counterfeit jasper” on fol. 10r presents three distinct processes for transforming horn: painting with colored varnish, applying dyed yarn, and shaping and coloring horn shavings into a “rose.” This essay discusses the author-practitioner’s experiential knowledge of horn and its intrinsic properties, particularly with regard to his attempt to make the resulting imitation jasper translucent, and his use of the terms “thin,” “luster,” and “fatty polish.” It examines a possible context for this recipe in Renaissance furniture inlay, especially the tarsia technique with inlays of stained woods, bone, and horn.

content.fullTitle: Gemstones and Imitation
content.name: Gemstones and Imitation
content.citeAs: Kremnitzer, Kathryn, Siddhartha Shah, and Pamela H. Smith. “Gemstones and Imitation.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_029_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/ajz5-bm67
content.abstract: Recipes for the making of gemstones appear in many texts and manuscripts from at least the seventh century BCE onward. Procedures to make gemstones typically involve the application of color to a transparent material, cracking a crystal to allow color to penetrate it, or the making of colored glass. While there are several entries in Ms. Fr. 640 for imitating and/or making use of precious and semi-precious stones, the nine recipes for pierrerie (gemstones) from fol. 100r to fol. 101v form a remarkably cohesive unit that appears to show the author-practitioner at work, gathering information from others, experimenting himself, and hypothesizing about how to overcome his failure. This essay compares his methods to other contemporary texts and considers whether these nine recipes provide clues to the author-practitioner’s identity.

content.fullTitle: Imitation Emeralds
content.name: Imitation Emeralds
content.citeAs: Shah, Siddhartha. “Imitation Emeralds.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_081_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/y541-c060
content.abstract: A recipe for Esmeraulde (emerald) on fol. 100v, one of a number of recipes for “Pierrerie” (Gemstones) in Ms. Fr. 640 lays out the materials and processes the author-practitioner uses for all gemstones, varying only the colorant. This is one of two recipes for making emeralds, the other on fol. 2v. This essay considers these recipes within the long history of emerald making, a practice apparently so widespread by the end of the sixteenth century that the author-practitioner could observe that “the common people make emeralds & cast in sand.” The reconstruction of this recipe necessitated multiple trials but resulted in the end in convincing emeralds.

content.fullTitle: Imitation Rubies and Failure in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Imitation Rubies and Failure
content.citeAs: Kremnitzer, Kathryn, and Pamela H. Smith. “Imitation Rubies and Failure in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_082_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/7qxw-2832
content.abstract: A recipe for ruby on fols. 100v–101r specifies mixing gold leaf with materials for making glass and heating to a temperature higher than for any other (imitation) gemstone. The author-practitioner failed at making ruby, as did most seekers of “gold ruby” glass, including multiple cohorts of Making and Knowing participants who reconstructed the process detailed in Ms. Fr. 640. This essay considers the crucial role of “imitation” and “failure” in stimulating the investigation of and experimentation on natural materials and processes.

content.fullTitle: Colors for Green Leaves and Painting on Metal
content.name: Colors for Green Leaves
content.citeAs: Kok, Cindy. “Colors for Green Leaves and Painting on Metal.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_030_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/s0h6-bs33
content.abstract: This essay explores three recipes in Ms. Fr. 640 (on fols. 158v, 10r, and 63v) that describe the making of a yellow-green paint to render metal casts of flowers more lifelike. The author-practitioner blends verdigris with an organic yellow lake pigment known as stil de grain yellow or scudegrun, and my reconstruction explores the different plant-based dyes and substrates he used for the yellow pigment. The author-practitioner’s experiments suggest a need for both precision and flexibility when imitating nature in the workshop: while the recipes can be specific about ingredients and ways to assess the naturalism of the pigment’s color, they also leave important components such as ingredient quantities and pigment application techniques up to a maker’s “judgment & discretion” (fol. 158v).

content.fullTitle: Damasked Cloth
content.name: Damasked Cloth
content.citeAs: Yi, Yuan. “Damasked Cloth.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_031_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/vgj0-yh50
content.abstract: An unusual recipe on fol. 15r involves resist-dye techniques to create a pattern on cloth that imitates damask textile. This essay reconstructs the dyes, and follows the entry’s instructions to reconstruct the process of resist-dyeing. It concludes by situating this process within other entries in Ms. Fr. 640 that aim to produce imitations of more expensive materials and to create the impermanent artworks and decorations of ephemeral court and civic festivals.

content.fullTitle: Color of Gold without Gold on Silver
content.name: Color of Gold without Gold on Silver
content.citeAs: Foyer, Emilie. “Color of Gold without Gold on Silver.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_032_fa_15. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/jz70-zv73
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 contains several recipes detailing techniques to imitate the optical properties of gold using less precious materials. Of these, two recipes (fols. 29v and 57r) detail the making of a “color of gold without gold on silver” by applying a golden colored varnish over silver leaf. The varnish derives its tint from terra merita, which the author-practitioner identifies as “turmeric root” (racine de cucurme) on fol. 148r. Yet much remains mysterious about terra merita, its preparation, and its use in the history of craft practice. This essay reconstructs the turmeric-based “gold without gold on silver,” and it investigates the occurrence of terra merita in artisanal texts and the use of yellow varnishes to color metals.

content.fullTitle: Rouge Clair: Glass or Paint?
content.name: Rouge Clair: Glass or Paint?
content.citeAs: Shi, Yuanxie, and Amy Chang. “Rouge Clair: Glass or Paint?” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_034_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/nb5d-a140
content.abstract: This essay explores a material called rouge clair, which is discussed in three separate entries in Ms. Fr. 640 on fols. 6r, 40v, and 124v. The term usually refers to a vitreous substance used for enameling, but the author-practitioner’s instructions complicate this definition: they include its use as a “cold enamel” that could be painted on metal without the use of heat. By reconstructing these entries and testing the application of the rouge clair produced, we conclude that for the author-practitioner, rouge clair did not necessarily refer to a specific substance (vitreous enamel), but rather to an optical effect that could be produced by different materials.

content.fullTitle: Apprenticeship of the Painter
content.name: Apprenticeship of the Painter
content.citeAs: Zhao, Wenrui. “Apprenticeship of the Painter.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_035_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/r9mm-je30
content.abstract: “Apprenticeship of the painter” on fol. 64v identifies the oval and the cross as fundamental shapes for aspiring artists to master. The disposition of the text and its accompanying sketches suggest something of the author-practitioner’s thought process in setting down his advice. This essay situates his notion of apprenticeship in the context of model books, art treatises, and artistic training in early modern Europe. While young artists were understood to require a knowledge of geometry and anatomy, this knowledge was of a practical and embodied kind—inculcated through the pedagogical practice of copying and aided by workshop shortcuts, such as the advice about the oval and the cross offered in Ms. Fr. 640.

content.fullTitle: Black Color for Dyeing, and the Place of Textiles in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Black Color for Dyeing
content.citeAs: Pitman, Sophie. “Black Color for Dyeing, and the Place of Textiles in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_036_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/acnf-0e59
content.abstract: Throughout BnF Ms. Fr. 640, the author-practitioner attempts to create black oils, stains, varnishes, pigments and—in one recipe—dye. Contextualizing the importance of black in the manuscript and in early modern society, this essay explores a short black dye recipe on fol. 38v which uses lead and lye made from quicklime. It then follows the author-practitioner’s instruction to “try other colors with the lye made of lime.” The essay proposes that while this method of dyeing degrades the fibers of wool and hair (and does not work on linens or silks), there is a “material logic” to the author-practitioner’s choice of materials if we place this recipe in context with his other experiments. While there is no substantial discussion of textiles or dyeing in Ms. Fr. 640, textiles make frequent occurrences in recipes as objects of transformation (either to be dyed, or to be used as a source for pigments), as subjects for painters, as tools, as similes, and as the object of useful knowledge. This essay argues that the author-practitioner demonstrates his “textile literacy” throughout the manuscript, including notes on the expense of black textiles, the accounting practices of cloth merchants, and the visual effects of clothing. Given the importance of the woad industry in Toulouse and the economic and cultural value of textiles in the early modern period, such knowledge and interest is understandable, but this essay prompts further questions about how widespread dye experimentation was in this period, the nuanced meaning of color in the region, and even what the author-practitioner might have been wearing as he carried out his experiments.

content.fullTitle: Dragon's Blood
content.name: Dragon's Blood
content.citeAs: Reich, Robin. “Dragon's Blood.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_037_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/428x-aq29
content.abstract: This essay explores the uses of a resinous material known as “dragon’s blood” in Ms. Fr. 640. Placing the relevant entries from the manuscript—including among others fols. 29v and 38v—in the context of sixteenth-century discussions of dragon’s blood in botany and medicine, it shows that its applications as a remedy and a colorant were informed by its material properties and symbolic correspondences between red, gold, and blood. An experimental exploration of its properties suggests possible explanations for its uses as a remedy and as an ingredient in colored varnishes.

content.fullTitle: What is Esmail in Ms. Fr. 640?
content.name: What is Esmail?
content.citeAs: Chang, Amy. “What is Esmail in Ms. Fr. 640?” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_038_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/mmbd-2191
content.abstract: This essay explores the meaning of esmail in Ms. Fr. 640 and places it in the context of historical enameling techniques. The term translates as “enamel,” but whereas this usually implies a vitreous substance produced using heat, in Ms. Fr. 640 it also encompasses materials with a glossy, enamel-like appearance without the application of heat, such as “cold enamels” which can be painted out, and in fact surpass vitreous enamels in their versatility and ease of application.

content.fullTitle: Gilding on Paper and Parchment
content.name: Gilding on Paper and Parchment
content.citeAs: Goldenberg, Lila. “Gilding on Paper and Parchment.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_039_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/a53m-jb79
content.abstract: Among recipes in BnF Ms. Fr. 640 devoted to gilding, two give instructions for laying gold leaf on paper and parchment, and these recipes distinguish themselves by their reliance on an unusual mordant made from wheat starch (fols. 10v and 29v). By reconstructing these recipes, this essay evaluates the possible ways in which this adhesive could have been used in the context of gilding on paper and parchment.

content.fullTitle: Imitation Marble
content.name: Imitation Marble
content.citeAs: Soley, Teresa. “Imitation Marble.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_040_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/tpgj-d438
content.abstract: A reconstruction of the entry “Varnish for distemper” on fol. 56r of BnF Ms. Fr. 640 shows that this particular varnish was not intended as a finishing layer to protect the paint and give it a sheen, as was customary in the sixteenth century. Instead, it functioned as an ingredient in the process and as a means of creating a specific optical effect—that of imitation marble.

content.fullTitle: What is Or Mat in Ms. Fr. 640?
content.name: What is Or Mat?
content.citeAs: Ndungu, Njeri. “What is Or Mat in Ms. Fr. 640?” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_041_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/dv6y-7c72
content.abstract: The term or mat occurs several times in Ms. Fr. 640, often alongside mentions of gold, gilding, and gold color. This essay reconstructs a recipe on fol. 66r, “Gilding molding for panels with or mat,” to flesh out the semantic richness of or mat in relation to the manuscript, contemporary artisanal and archival sources, modern conservation literature, museum objects, and the strange etymological development of the term. Ultimately, this essay argues that or mat should be considered neither as a material nor as a technique exclusively. Rather, early modern conceptual understandings of the term seem to point to the inextricability of the optical effects of the material from the processes of its making.

content.fullTitle: Shadows Beneath the Skin: How to Paint Faces in Distemper
content.name: Shadows Beneath the Skin
content.citeAs: Nisse, Cleo. “Shadows Beneath the Skin: How to Paint Faces in Distemper.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_042_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/a6bs-0765
content.abstract: In an entry on fol. 93v titled “Face in distemper,” the author-practitioner describes a method for depicting a face in paint on canvas. This essay analyzes that entry, contextualizing it in relation to other painting recipes in the manuscript and to other early modern artisanal treatises, before turning to laboratory reconstruction. Ms. Fr. 640 points to the intertwined relationship between representing skin and the body’s shadows, thereby reflecting broader concerns of early modern artistic practice. The author-practitioner also advises altering the hue of flesh shading by gender, which may owe something to humoral theory. Among the pigments he suggests using for male shadows is jet, a substance rarely mentioned in other painting treatises. The results of the reconstructions suggest that the specific paint medium intended by the term “distemper” may have been glue, but this is not conclusive and further experimentation is necessary.

content.fullTitle: Sleight of Hand Tricks
content.name: Sleight of Hand Tricks
content.citeAs: Barwich, Ann-Sophie. “Sleight of Hand Tricks.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_043_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/rfq6-0k88
content.abstract: A set of recipes on fols. 33r–43v in Ms. Fr. 640 is dedicated to sleight of hand. These tricks are part of a larger canon of “secrets” performed at public places, such as markets and taverns, and transmitted over several centuries and across the globe. Traditionally, conjuring tricks were judged to be deceptive and therefore illicit. Prominent sixteenth-century scholars like Reginald Scot and Agrippa von Nettesheim were determined to debunk such performances as fraudulent. Meanwhile, these feats of practical magic also conveyed early forms of specialist knowledge in mathematics (riddles), physics and astronomy (optical effects), chemistry (transmutation), and theatrical display (mechanical props). This essay examines the social life of sleight of hand in its widespread cultural transmission. This study also discovers striking similarities between entries in Ms. Fr. 640 and Jean Prevost’s Clever and Pleasant Inventions (Lyon, 1584), especially on fols. 33r, 33v, 34v, 35r, and 35v.

content.fullTitle: Sulfuric Acid for the Scribe
content.name: Sulfuric Acid for the Scribe
content.citeAs: Clemens, Olivia. “Sulfuric Acid for the Scribe.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_044_sp_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/h470-b808
content.abstract: Oil of sulfur, composed primarily of sulfuric acid, is a corrosive mineral acid with many applications. In Ms. Fr. 640, however, the material is almost exclusively mentioned on a single folio (fol. 46r–v) in a series of recipes possibly copied from a source referred to as “Urb.” This essay studies and recreates a selection of these recipes, focusing on those in which oil of sulfur is used as a material for a scribe—as an invisible ink, in creating openwork in paper, as a cleaning agent for quills, and for removing ink from parchment. While numerous contemporary books of secrets include recipes for invisible inks and ink removal, often requiring acids like citrus juice, no other known sources specifically use oil of sulfur for these purposes. This novel application of oil of sulfur serves as a valuable case study of the use of mineral acids in early modern craft processes, as well as early modern techniques for invisible ink and erasure.

content.fullTitle: Imitating Raw Nature
content.name: Imitating Raw Nature
content.citeAs: Lores-Chavez, Isabella. “Imitating Raw Nature.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_045_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/a9xc-m996
content.abstract: Several recipes in Ms. Fr. 640 refer to artistic practices of imitating nature. The author-practitioner appears to distinguish between imiter and contrefaire: to “counterfeit” means to create imitations of raw materials that can adequately stand in for the original. This material mimesis is based on firsthand knowledge of the raw substance and presents an opportunity for inquiry about nature’s own processes of creation. The endeavor to create a manmade equivalent impels the artisan to examine closely the peculiarities of the raw material and to seek practicable techniques that can match (without supplanting) nature’s creative forces. This essay examines and reconstructs the recipe for Jaspe contrefaict (Counterfeit Jasper) on fol. 10r as a case study and point from which to begin to contextualize the author-practitioner’s interest in imitation. This essay proposes connections between his modes of inquiry into the physical properties of raw nature and important sixteenth-century epistemological projects, including the Kunstkammer and the work of naturalists theorizing about the geological origins of stones.

content.fullTitle: Pain, Ostie, Rostie: Bread in Early Modern Europe
content.name: Bread in Early Modern Europe
content.citeAs: Le Pouésard, Emma. “Pain, Ostie, Rostie: Bread in Early Modern Europe.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_046_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/vmhr-4038
content.abstract: What is bread in the context of Ms. Fr. 640? This category of food appears in the manuscript under three different names: bread, host (37r), and toast (79v, 123v). The meaning and use of these terms are considered as well as the production of bread and Hosts in the early modern period and the pathways by which bread could have entered the author-practitioner’s workshop. Flour was the key factor in bread production, often selected by availability, preference, and beliefs about particular cereals. The baking practices required for different grains influenced the breads one could bake. Some, such as oatbread, could be baked on the hearth at home; others, such as fine wheat bread, required the high and constant heat of a specialized oven and were chiefly baked professionally. The varieties of flours, breads, and processes show the meaning of “bread” in the period of the manuscript’s compilation cannot be taken for granted.

content.fullTitle: Spinet Playing by Itself
content.name: Spinet Playing by Itself
content.citeAs: Hiebert, Benjamin. “Spinet Playing by Itself.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_047_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/8j31-mv52
content.abstract: The cursory description on fol. 104v of an automatic, mechanical version of the spinet, a plucked-stringed keyboard instrument, is one of a handful of entries on music or mechanics in Ms. Fr. 640. The author-practitioner likely had some familiarity with plucked-stringed instruments and possessed a curiosity for “invention,” a term he used to describe the automatic spinet and one with broader meaning in the sixteenth century than it has today. An automatic spinet would have belonged within relatively elite social circles, and it shares technical features with musical automata of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. A scaled-down reconstruction questions the likelihood that the author-practitioner ever undertook the entry’s instructions himself. Rather, the “Spinet” entry probably resulted from his interests and encounters, reminding readers that the manuscript should sometimes be seen as a collection of thoughts and observations as well as a practical guidebook.

content.fullTitle: Smoke as Medicine
content.name: Smoke as Medicine
content.citeAs: DeVinney, Joslyn. “Smoke as Medicine.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_048_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/kfja-0v86
content.abstract: Of over forty medicinal entries in BnF Ms. Fr. 640, “Medicine of the Orientals against all maladies” is the only recipe that advises taking in the smoke of a dried herb as a treatment. This recipe, on fol. 77r, is also the only reference to “oriental medicine” in the manuscript and the sole example of the use of a pipe to make smoke. In other parts of the manuscript, however, the author-practitioner includes numerous references to good and bad smoke, breath, and vapors in the context of bodily health and craft techniques. This essay discusses this recipe's relationship to others in Ms. Fr. 640, offering insights into the author-practitioner’s conceptions of medicinal materials and practices, and the overlap between medical and non-medical processes in the manuscript. To further situate “Medicine of the orientals against all maladies,” this essay explores its possible genealogy within global medicinal practices. These interconnections demonstrate the importance of historicizing artisanal and medical practice and their related knowledge systems.

content.fullTitle: Keeping Dry Flowers in the Same State All Year
content.name: Keeping Dry Flowers
content.citeAs: Sellar, Caitlyn. “Keeping Dry Flowers in the Same State All Year.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_049_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/jg4j-wx69
content.abstract: The recipe “Keeping dry flowers in the same state all year” (fol. 120v–121r) reflects the author-practitioner’s wider preoccupation with the preservation of flora and fauna for display. In this recipe, he provides instructions for drying a particular set of flowers with sand and preserving them in vases of vinegar. Through an examination of the language of the recipe as well as his uses of vinegar, sand, and flowers elsewhere in the manuscript, this essay seeks to highlight the author-practitioner's familiarity with sand and vinegar as preservative materials and postulates that an accumulation of botanical knowledge likely informed his attempt to achieve a more lifelike result. Moreover, his selection of flowers suggests that he was attuned to the cultural meanings of flowers and floral decoration in the late sixteenth century. A reconstruction of the recipe demonstrates that extensive knowledge of the materials is important not only to the outcome but to their handling. The author-practitioner’s vague instructions suggest that he was familiar with the processes of preservation he describes, further underscoring his experience with and interest in preserving organic materials.

content.fullTitle: Bread as Mediating Material: Tactile Memory and Touch
content.name: Bread as Mediating Material
content.citeAs: Le Pouésard, Emma. “Bread as Mediating Material: Tactile Memory and Touch,” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_050_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/51fz-0r94
content.abstract: This essay addresses the role of materials not as physical ingredients or tools but as mediators between familiar and unfamiliar processes, taking bread and baking in the manuscript as a case study. References to bread in entries that do not employ this food use the familiar activity of baking to elucidate unfamiliar technical processes, such as when making stucco, to “knead it as if you wanted to make bread” (fol. 29r). The author-practitioner turns assumed tactile memories in his reader into descriptive devices and implies the primacy of touch in craft practice. Current neuroscientific research argues that touch is the most sensitive of the senses and is strongly linked to memory-making; this might help explain the prominence of tactile descriptions in craft and technical writing. The use of familiar materials and processes as mediators in written accounts enables craftspeople recording procedural and embodied knowledge to bridge the gap between experience and words.

content.fullTitle: Black Sulfured Wax
content.name: Black Sulfured Wax
content.citeAs: Kang, Charles. “Black Sulfured Wax.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_051_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/n0dk-t202
content.abstract: A recipe for a mixture of wax, charcoal, and sulfur referred to as “black sulfured wax” appears on fol. 139v of Ms. Fr. 640. This essay contextualizes the mixture in relation to other wax compounds described in the manuscript and other craft treatises. Reconstructions of the black sulfured compound and two other wax variants were used to test the author-practitioner’s claims about the physical properties and practical uses of black sulfured wax. Only a limited number of these claims could be confirmed. Further work will have to experiment with varying the quantities of ingredients and mixing temperatures. It appears that the “black sulfured wax” was both a variation of the practice—common among early modern artisans—of mixing wax with black additives, and an extension of the author-practitioner’s many experiments with sulfur and wax.

content.fullTitle: Glassworking in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Glassworking
content.citeAs: Donefer-Hickie, Ana Matisse. “Glassworking in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_052_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/4b00-br57
content.abstract: The entry “For cages” on fol. 6v describes a specialized glassworking process, the manipulation of glass canes for lampworking and beadmaking. Third person description suggests that the author-practitioner observed glassworkers lengthening hollow canes, and his familiarity with particular tools, materials, and processes used in lampworking and beadmaking support this hypothesis. While functional cages for keeping animals are discussed elsewhere in the manuscript, “For cages” is situated among other entries concerning the embellishment of readymade objects and suggests the author-practitioner’s interest in applying the decorative techniques of lampworkers. My reconstruction suggests ways to fuse and bend wire and glass that could be learned by observation or developed experimentally by someone without extensive training. The author-practitioner’s attention to various glassworking industries and their specialized products in Ms. Fr. 640 suggests that he used technical knowledge gathered from encounters with other artisans to inform and augment his own wide-ranging artisanal activities.

content.fullTitle: Buckram Sausage and Gunpowder Weapons
content.name: Buckram Sausage and Gunpowder Weapons
content.citeAs: Fong, Sau-yi. “Buckram Sausage and Gunpowder Weapons.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_053_fa_16. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/r29b-gc54
content.abstract: Embedded within an untitled entry that focuses on mortiers (“mortars,” here meaning “petards”), fol. 23r–23v includes text and image instructions to make a “buckram sausage,” a sausage-shaped fabric tube filled with gunpowder used as a fuse for short-range artillery. While Ms. Fr. 640 contains more than twenty entries related to gunpowder technology, the buckram sausage passages are among the very few instances of highly specific textual and visual instructions on the materials, techniques, and procedures of weapon production. Using hands-on reconstruction and research into the artisanal production of weapons in early modern Europe, this essay also explores the possible uses of the buckram sausage on the battlefield and examines how the author-practitioner engages with contemporaneous military technology in his writing. Finally, this essay calls attention to the importance of wartime contingencies and commonplace techniques in understanding the translation between practical and textual knowledge with regard to early modern military technology.

content.fullTitle: Gout or Gonorrhea? The Riddle of G.
content.name: Gout or Gonorrhea?
content.citeAs: Basile, Nicole. “Gout or Gonorrhea? The Riddle of G.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_054_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/pc0c-te91
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640, fol. 7v, contains a curious recipe titled “To relieve the pain of G.” This essay seeks to uncover the meaning of “G.” in this entry by comparing the recipe to three other similar entries in the manuscript: “Against gonorrhea,” also on fol. 7v, “Against Go.,” on fol. 16v, and “Against cold gouts,” on fol. 46r. Contemporary sources, including medical treatises and reference works, offer clues about the purpose of this recipe, mentioning similar ingredients and methods of preparation and application. Indeed, the medicinal properties of the recipe’s ingredients—marcasite, storax, and urine—serve specific purposes that can be associated with early modern conceptions of gout. A reconstruction of the recipe considers whether the process of distilling these ingredients was feasible.

content.fullTitle: Distillation in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Distillation in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Eom, Christopher. “Distillation in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_055_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/ngen-ex30
content.abstract: Innovations in distillation practices and technology in early modern Europe made possible the production of distillates in larger quantities. Such technologies became a prerequisite for a variety of modern-day applications in laboratory sciences and medicinal chemistry that followed. Ms. Fr. 640 provides testimony to this development: an illustration on fol. 3v of a distillation vessel raises questions about where this apparatus can be located within this context, as well as about the author-practitioner’s knowledge and practice of distillation. This essay considers the text and image of the entry in the context of the manuscript, and it speculates about the consequences of the entry’s overriding concern with the practical yield of the apparatus, in quantity, quality, and variety of products.

content.fullTitle: Making and Using Fish Glue
content.name: Making and Using Fish Glue
content.citeAs: Wang, Xinguo. “Making and Using Fish Glue.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_056_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/ya5j-rm35
