content.abstract: Glue is any substance that creates a bond between two separate objects or that prepares the surface for subsequent operations. In Ms. Fr. 640, fish glue in particular plays an important role in glueing delicate items. The author-practitioner, however, especially emphasizes two characteristics—clearness and strength of the glue—throughout the manuscript. Thus, I reconstructed three kinds of fish glue with different parts of the fish based on the recipe on fol. 7r in order to examine the reliability of the author-practitioner’s statements about making fish glue and, further, to demonstrate his comprehensive understanding of its use.

content.fullTitle: Collecting Cures in an Artisanal Manuscript: Practical Therapeutics and Disease in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Collecting Cures
content.citeAs: Liu, Xiaomeng. “Collecting Cures in an Artisanal Manuscript: Practical Therapeutics and Disease in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_057_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/wq5p-p848
content.abstract: Scattered throughout Ms. Fr. 640, the forty medical recipes form a small percentage of its over 900 entries. A consideration of the ailments, ingredients, and making processes described in the manuscript, as well as the author-practitioner’s process of collecting information, reveals a variety of connections between Ms. Fr. 640’s medical recipes and early modern artisanal work.

content.fullTitle: Acid as Dental Cleanser and Tooth-Whitening Practices
content.name: Acid as Dental Cleanser
content.citeAs: Liu, Xiaomeng. “Acid as Dental Cleanser and Tooth-Whitening Practices.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_058_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/6ccz-7c74
content.abstract: “For the teeth, oil of sulfur” on fol. 46r of Ms. Fr. 640 requires eau forte (nitric acid) and “oil of sulfur” (sulfuric acid) as materials for teeth whitening. The recipe records the effects of both acids as well as their “side effects” and ways to counteract them. The organization of this recipe shows the author-practitioner was recording different approaches to whitening teeth rather than providing a tested remedy. The reconstruction of the recipe demonstrates the efficacy of the remedies, while the side effects would likely be revealed only after long term use.

content.fullTitle: The Reconstruction of a Medicinal Plaster
content.name: Medicinal Plaster
content.citeAs: Liu, Xiaomeng. “The Reconstruction of a Medicinal Plaster.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_079_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/7kns-9d53
content.abstract: The reconstruction of the recipe on fol. 66v for preventing the swelling of breasts makes clear the problems of reconstructing historical medical recipes. The curative aim of the recipe is not clear. Plant materials are difficult to identify and to source, and testing of the efficacy of the substance produced is neither feasible, safe, nor ethical.

content.fullTitle: An Excellent Salve for Burns
content.name: Salve for Burns
content.citeAs: Liu, Xiaomeng. “An Excellent Salve for Burns.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_080_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/58dr-ns42
content.abstract: “Against burns, excellent” (fol. 103r) gives detailed instructions on the making and application of a salve for burns. Like some other medical recipes in the manuscript it calls for relatively few ingredients but specifies a complex making process to transform the material into a different state. The recipe is unusual among the other medical recipes in Ms. Fr. 640, however, because it possesses explicit spiritual dimensions, including pure ingredients, holy water, and the recitation of prayers. In addition, the recipe provides information about its source and trustworthiness. The reconstruction of the recipe revealed the transformation of the mixture of linseed oil and hardening wax, two hydrophobic substances, into a fluffy white ointment through constant stirring with water, and, at the same time, the purifying “ritual” brought about a visible whitening and “inspiriting” of the materials with each recited prayer and washing with holy water.

content.fullTitle: Silkworms and the Work of Algiers
content.name: Silkworms and the Work of Algiers
content.citeAs: Grafit, Sasha. “Silkworms and the Work of Algiers.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_059_sp_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/adew-hy48
content.abstract: The author-practitioner’s detailed description of how to raise silkworms according to conventional early modern sericultural methods in “Silkworms” on fol. 53v is related by material and timing to a quite unusual entry on fol. 52r, “The work done in Algiers.” This entry involves raising a silkworm in a flask to produce a powder that transforms antimony into gold. “The work done in Algiers” also relates to another entry in BnF Ms. Fr. 640 for creating a strong poison by putrefying snails in a flask. Taken together, these recipes fall into a genre of alchemical recipes for producing strong agents by putrefying small but symbolic creatures in flasks. This annotation explores the movement of this complex of ideas and practices from China to North Africa to Toulouse. My reconstruction suggests that “Silkworms” and “The work done in Algiers” serve as examples of Ms. Fr. 640 as both a practical record and as encouraging its user to tread into realms of as yet untested knowledge.

content.fullTitle: What is Azur in Ms. Fr. 640?
content.name: What is Azur in Ms. Fr. 640?
content.citeAs: Garris, Carl. “What is Azur in Ms. Fr. 640?” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_060_fa_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/e115-w212
content.abstract: Throughout Ms. Fr. 640, the author-practitioner uses azur to refer to blue pigments. It is not clear if this means azur in a general sense of “blue color” or as a reference to specific pigments. Analyzing historical uses of the term azur can give insight into the linguistic and artistic landscape in which the author-practitioner operated. The four most likely pigments to which azur could refer are azurite, lapis lazuli, smalt, and verditer (synthetic azurite). In tabulating textual occurrences of azur to isolate patterns of use, azur, azur desmail, cendres dazur, and azur dacre emerge as significant. Through reconstruction of entries involving azur (fol. 11r), we found qualitative data to support a tentative historical identification of cendres dazur with verditer. Although azur desmail would seem to denote smalt, we as yet lack experimental justification for this conclusion. The reconstructions carried out for this essay demonstrate the complexity of blue pigment making and application during the Renaissance, and allow us to draw very tentative conclusions as to the identity of some of the manuscript’s terms for blue pigments.

content.fullTitle: What is Carton?
content.name: What is Carton?
content.citeAs: Dongchung, Tenzin. “What is Carton?” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_061_fa_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/xwg0-2e10
content.abstract: This essay focuses on the entry “Carton” on fol. 81r, which describes how paper can be pulped and molded in a cavity. This description at first appears similar to the process of using paper that later became known as papier-mâché. The research on the historical meaning and uses of carton in this essay, and its examination of references to carton in both Ms. Fr. 640 and contemporaneous French literature demonstrates that, while many uses of carton were similar to those of papier-mâché, carton was also employed in ways not associated with papier-mâché. By examining the multiple functions of carton—as a cheaper mold substitute, or as an element in composite decorative objects, for example—this essay sheds light on the capacious understanding of the material in early modern Europe.

content.fullTitle: Painting in Oil on Taffeta II
content.name: Painting in Oil on Taffeta II
content.citeAs: Yar, Sumeyye. “Painting in Oil on Taffeta II.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_062_fa_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/nfa3-nj72
content.abstract: Two recipes in BnF Ms. Fr. 640 (fols. 42v and 10v) describe oil painting on taffeta “without the oil running.” However, these recipes contain no information about what exactly is meant by “oil running,” what the exact ingredients or their quantities are, and why there are two different recipes in the manuscript for the same purpose. Exploring these questions, this reconstruction shows that when prepared at certain ratios, applying a sizing mixture over the surface of the taffeta serves to prevent oil paint from seeping into the taffeta fibers, and thus stops its diffusion.

content.fullTitle: Artificial Grottos
content.name: Artificial Grottos
content.citeAs: Ullman, Reut. “Artificial Grottos.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_063_fa_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/26md-x363
content.abstract: Fifteenth and sixteenth-century artificial grottos were popular garden ornaments for Europe’s wealthiest elites. But in the late sixteenth century scholars have noted a growing prevalence of lightweight artificial grottos in theater productions and celebratory festivities. Multiple entries in Ms. Fr. 640 provide instructions for ornamenting an artificial grotto with lightweight materials. An historical study of literature thematically similar and contemporaneous to Ms. Fr. 640, followed by a reconstruction of the recipes for Grottes (Grottos) from fols. 40r and 118r, suggests that the artificial grotto the author-practitioner ornamented was likely intended for a festival.

content.fullTitle: Stucco for Molding
content.name: Stucco for Molding
content.citeAs: Elizondo-Garza, Nina. “Stucco for Molding.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_064_fa_17. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/1n6h-5f69
content.abstract: The entry “Stucco for molding” on fol. 29r describes a method for creating stucco which the author-practitioner claims is versatile and inexpensive. This essay offers a material-based analysis of the entry, drawing on insights from laboratory reconstructions, and a historical investigation of ancient and early modern stucco recipes and stucco use to better situate the author-practitioner within his context. These comparisons reveal that the author-practitioner’s recipe, particularly its use of tragacanth gum, is unusual. Moreover, the entry highlights the author-practitioner’s interest in ornamentation, his focus on using pre-existing patterns rather than creating new ones, and his possible first-hand experiences of making domestic and ephemeral decorative art.

content.fullTitle: To Corrode and Dissolve: Making Aquafortis in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Making Aquafortis
content.citeAs: Assis, Michael. “To Corrode and Dissolve: Making Aquafortis in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_065_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/z4f5-5m60
content.abstract: This essay explores the ambiguous meanings of aquafortis, of its constituent ingredients, and of the units of measurement listed in “For making aquafortis” on fol. 75r. By situating the recipe within a broader historical context, aquafortis can be understood as a substance with the ability to interact with solids, and perform actions such as dissolve or corrode metals. Comparison of the recipe in Ms. Fr. 640 with contemporary textual sources gives insight into the variety of uses for aquafortis and the various ingredients for making it. This indicates that the term copperas refers to any sulfate (vitriol), and solle refers to salt (NaCl) rather than saltpeter. The genres of texts containing aquafortis recipes reveal that the recipes in Ms. Fr. 640 bear comparison with a variety of literary traditions: alchemical manuscripts, metallurgical treatises, treatises on arts, and books of secrets. Finally, the recipe for aquafortis on fol. 75r was reconstructed, which showed the efficacy of the recipe and its correspondence with contemporary expectations about aquafortis.

content.fullTitle: La Maison Rustique: Cultivation and the Genre of the Household Manual
content.name: Cultivation and the Genre of the Household Manual
content.citeAs: Bergen, Katie. “La Maison Rustique: Cultivation and the Genre of the Household Manual.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_066_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/kn1e-7828
content.abstract: A significant proportion of the entries in Ms. Fr. 640 describe the cultivation of plants and animals. Might this indicate a conceptual link between the manuscript and the genre of the household manual? This essay investigates Charles Estienne’s La maison rustique (1564), a popular manual contemporary with the manuscript, to delineate divergences and convergences between Ms. Fr. 640 and the genre. While both works concern the human capacity to intervene in the natural world, Ms. Fr. 640 is more piecemeal in its approach to cultivation practices, concerned with the instrumental uses of plants and animals rather than the long-term management of the land, as La maison rustique is.

content.fullTitle: Transferring Images
content.name: Transferring Images
content.citeAs: Bertozzi, Nicolle. “Transferring Images.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_067_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/qmcq-ce66
content.abstract: BnF Ms. Fr. 640 contains a number of entries about image transfer techniques, including “For writing as well from the left as from the right” (fol. 19v), “Pounced design for scratching satin” (42v), and “Making counterproofs” (51r). Using reconstruction and historical research, this essay considers these image transfer techniques in terms of the principles they employ and the ways they transform the original image in the process of transferring it onto a new surface. It compares these entries with an image transfer technique used in Tokugawa Japanese woodblock printing, examining in particular whether the techniques transfer the image as a mirror image and the degree to which the techniques destroy the original image in the process. This comparison reveals that the technique used to transfer an image from one surface to another is inherently intertwined with the kinds of values that are assigned to the original image and its copy.

content.fullTitle: Tablets
content.name: Tablets
content.citeAs: Bostock, Sahar. “Tablets.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_068_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/8ev4-pf02
content.abstract: A three-line entry on fol. 15v notes the material qualities, ornamentation, and use of metalpoint tablets or “writing tables.” This essay seeks to understand the physical characteristics of the tablet that the author-practitioner had in mind and the context in which he might have used it. The essay surveys the history of tablets, from ancient and medieval wooden tablets inlaid with wax to early modern varieties made of coated paper and parchment for writing and metalpoint drawing. Several contemporary manuscripts feature recipes for a ground that could be applied to different supports, written on with a metal stylus, erased, and reused. As the author-practitioner makes no mention of any ground, the reconstruction examines possible reasons for such an omission. The essay speculates that the author-practitioner may have used a tablet like the one he describes—perhaps an erasable notebook made by an expert in which he could record his observations temporarily before he transferred them to his final manuscript.

content.fullTitle: Necessary Particulars: Philosophical Reflections on Making and Knowing with Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Necessary Particulars
content.citeAs: Branscum, Olivia. “Necessary Particulars: Philosophical Reflections on Making and Knowing with Ms. Fr. 640,” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_069_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/2ap7-d967
content.abstract: This essay reflects philosophically on how the Making and Knowing Project engages with Ms. Fr. 640 to gain insight into artisanal epistemology. I draw a distinction between “virtual” and “concrete” modes of investigating the manuscript before arguing that it should be studied using both modes in an interwoven manner. I track the problematic virtual/concrete distinction through some recent scholarship, and I suggest that texts like Ms. Fr. 640, which combine records of craft practice with evidence of engagement in those practices, call for a reevaluation of epistemological categories such as propositional and practical knowledge in order to better understand artisanal ways of knowing.

content.fullTitle: Tin and its Uses in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Tin and its Uses
content.citeAs: Buckley, James. “Tin and its Uses in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_070_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/j0qh-a159
content.abstract: This essay explores the author-practitioner’s knowledge of tin. It compares the discussion of tin and its properties in Ms. Fr. 640 to those found in contemporary works, such as Georgius Agricola’s De re metallica, Vannoccio Biringuccio’s Pirotechnia, and Lazarus Ercker’s Beschreibung allerfürnemisten mineralischen Ertzt und Berckwercksarten. Of particular interest are the author-practitioner’s qualifiers for tin, which include doux, fin, and aigre. A historical reconstruction of a recipe on fol. 6v for creating tin ornaments considers the author-practitioner’s tacit knowledge about metalworking and the social context for decorative tin objects.

content.fullTitle: Black Varnish for Armor
content.name: Black Varnish for Armor
content.citeAs: Camps, Celine. “Black Varnish for Armor.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_071_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/5qhq-ky36
content.abstract: Historians know little about how armor was made black. This essay starts to fill the lacuna by examining a sixteenth-century recipe, “Black varnish for sword guard, bands for trunks, etc.,” on fol. 4v of Ms. Fr. 640. What was black varnish for armor? How was it made and applied? What ingredients and techniques were used? What purposes did it serve? Using a combination of reconstruction and textual research, this essay suggests that “Black varnish for sword guard” was used as an etching ground, a rust-protection coat, and a finish to impart luster and brilliance to armor and metals. The reconstructions underpinning this essay give insights into the varnish ingredients and show that success (or failure) in making and applying black varnish depended as much on the properties of the ingredients as on an artisan’s knowledge of heat, metals, and tools—as well as the skill of working with them.

content.fullTitle: Ms. Fr. 640 and The Jewell House of Art and Nature (1594)
content.name: Ms. Fr. 640 and The Jewell House
content.citeAs: Faulkner, Amanda. “Ms. Fr. 640 and The Jewell House of Art and Nature (1594).” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_072_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/w16g-zd09
content.abstract: This essay compares BnF Ms. Fr. 640 with The Jewell House of Art and Nature (1594) by Hugh Plat. It considers similarities and differences between these two works and analyzes areas of overlap. I argue that Plat, for all his emphasis on experiential knowledge, probably had less personal experience of casting, molding, and weapons than the author-practitioner. I explore the local contexts and knowledge networks in which the texts were produced, and how the author-practitioner and Plat dealt with the issue of secrets in their works. This comparison of the two texts highlights the importance of experience and exchange in early modern knowledge networks.

content.fullTitle: Polishing and Engraving Stones
content.name: Polishing and Engraving Stones
content.citeAs: Jiang, Angel. “Polishing and Engraving Stones.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_074_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/gsf2-ph07
content.abstract: This essay reconstructs two recipes concerning the treatment of precious stones. The first, “For Diamond Points for Engraving” (fol. 11v), offers instructions to trace a design onto a stone in preparation for engraving. The second, “Polishing of Stones” (fol. 13r), concerns the polishing of already engraved or faceted stones. By reconstructing two processes practiced by goldsmiths, this essay aims to clarify the extent of the author-practitioner's knowledge of a specialized craft.

content.fullTitle: What is Stone in Ms. Fr. 640?
content.name: What is Stone?
content.citeAs: Jiang, Angel. “What is Stone in Ms. Fr. 640?“ In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_075_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/w8g1-yt97
content.abstract: This essay addresses the ontology of stone in BnF Ms. Fr. 640. What is stone to the author-practitioner, both in the manuscript as a repository of knowledge and the workshop as a site of production? What constitutes a stone and what distinguishes it from other natural resources and usable objects? How does the author-practitioner demonstrate and produce knowledge about stone as a material by exploiting its material properties, and to what end? Analysis suggests five categories to classify the author-practitioner’s understanding and use of stone: tools and supports, materials, matrices, gemstones, and reference materials. Stone is revealed to be a varied and versatile material for transformation and use.

content.fullTitle: To Shrink an Object: Bread Molding in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: To Shrink an Object
content.citeAs: Lim, Min. “To Shrink an Object: Bread Molding in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020 https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_076_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/vsnc-4x81
content.abstract: “To Shrink an Object” examines the process on fol. 140v for varying the shape or size of an impression in a mold made from bread, which is subsequently cast with sulfur. It situates this bread molding recipe in its historical context—of bread molding methods as well as uses of bread and bread making in craft and artistic practices—in the period of the manuscript’s compilation. The reconstruction tests the viability of this process, specifically, the entry’s instructions to dry the bread in order to reduce the size of an impression in a bread mold, and thus of the subsequently cast object, in relation to the original pattern used to make the imprint. Reconstruction shows that the types of bread used, along with the preparation of the bread pith, influence the extent of the shrinkage. Reheating a bread mold also hastened the shrinking process that occurred when imprints were left to dry naturally. The longer the molds were reheated, the more the impressions decreased in size.

content.fullTitle: Wax for Seals in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Wax for Seals
content.citeAs: Olson, Nancy. “Wax for Seals in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_077_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/ycat-6k25
content.abstract: Wax is a frequently used material in Ms. Fr. 640. Two entries on fols. 42r and 133r use wax for making “seals,” although the types of seals the author-practitioner had in mind are unclear. This essay explores wax seals for documents in early modern Europe. The reconstructions seek to evaluate the efficacy of the author-practitioner’s techniques for producing superior seals. The first reconstruction demonstrates that his methods for preparing and pressing wax for imprinting can yield a large seal that was as well formed as one made using an alternative technique involving pouring molten wax. The second reconstruction, which explores additives that give a greater hardness to wax, produced less conclusive results, in part because of uncertainty about how much lead white and how much pigment were to be added to a given quantity of wax.

content.fullTitle: Pinking Satin
content.name: Pinking Satin
content.citeAs: Bertozzi, Nicolle. “Pinking Satin.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_078_fa_18. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/5s39-j049
content.abstract: This short essay investigates the meaning of “scratching satin” on fol. 42v and identifies it with the technique known as “pinking,” that is to say, creating a pattern by means of cuts in the fabric.

content.fullTitle: An Introduction to Ms. Fr. 640 and its Author-Practitioner
content.name: Introduction to Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Smith, Pamela H. “An Introduction to Ms. Fr. 640 and its Author-Practitioner.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_300_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/ny3t-qg71
content.abstract: This critical edition of the late sixteenth-century anonymous manuscript cataloged as Ms. Fr. 640 in the Bibliothèque nationale de France was created through the work of team members, students, and collaborators of the Making and Knowing Project at Columbia University. The technical and artistic “recipes” contained in Ms. Fr. 640 provide an outstanding opportunity to explore the epistemic and historical intersections between craft making and scientific knowing, especially in light of the emergence of a new science in the following centuries. Ms. Fr. 640 provides important insights into the material, technical, and intellectual worlds of late sixteenth-century Europe, and brings a better understanding of how and why nature was investigated, used in art, and collected and appreciated in early modern Europe. It sheds light, as well, on the type of knowledge possessed by handworkers, known today as “practical knowledge,” “how-to,” or “makers’ knowledge.” At the heart of the Edition of Ms. Fr. 640, however, lies an intriguing puzzle: who was the anonymous individual who wrote down (and in many cases tried out) these 930 entries filling 170 folios, and why did a French nobleman collect and preserve this manuscript?

content.fullTitle: The Manuscript Seen from Afar: A Computational Approach to Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: A Computational Approach to Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Godbarge, Clément. “The Manuscript Seen from Afar: A Computational Approach to Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_301_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/nnyc-gd81
content.abstract: Using the abundant data made available by the Making and Knowing Project, this essay examines some of the rhetorical features of Ms. Fr. 640, with a focus on dispositio. It argues that, when applied to a single document, careful visualization of statistical data can promote a “synthetic” approach to texts. Applied to Ms. Fr. 640, these computational methods provide readers with tools to assess relations between the manuscript’s constitutive parts and its cohesion as a whole. In doing so, this essay contributes to broadening the scope of computer-assisted hermeneutics in data-rich editions.

content.fullTitle: The Body and the Senses in Ms. Fr. 640: Towards a "Material Sensorium"
content.name: The Body and the Senses in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Taape, Tillmann. “The Body and the Senses in Ms. Fr. 640: Towards a ‘Material Sensorium.’” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_302_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/027y-d055
content.abstract: This essay explores the “material sensorium” of the author-practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640, that is to say, his discussions of the senses and their place in his project of making and knowing. The manuscript presents a unique opportunity to explore the senses as a site of bidirectional exchange between the human body and the materials with which it works.

content.fullTitle: "Experience Will Teach You": Recording, Testing, Knowing, and the Language of Experience in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: The Language of Experience in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Taape, Tillmann. “'Experience Will Teach You': Recording, Testing, Knowing, and the Language of Experience in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_303_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/njnq-6q58
content.abstract: This essay explores the language of experience in Ms. Fr. 640 to characterize the place of experiential knowledge in the author-practitioner’s epistemology. Based on a concordance search of the terms experience, experimenter, essayer, esprouver, and cognoistre, the essay highlights the author-practitioner’s often overlapping use of these words and how they map onto the modes of writing down experience that can be identified in the manuscript: inferences from repeated experience, accounts of singular events, specific material tests, and invitations to further testing.

content.fullTitle: Within the Workshop Walls and Beyond: The Spaces of Artisanal Experiment and Inquiry
content.name: The Spaces of Artisanal Experiment and Inquiry
content.citeAs: Uchacz, Tianna Helena. “Within the Workshop Walls and Beyond: The Spaces of Artisanal Experiment and Inquiry.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2025. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_304_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/kwkz-n680
content.abstract: The author-practitioner of BnF Ms. Fr. 640 rarely describes the spaces he works in or moves through; his focus is almost exclusively on activities of making. Nevertheless, spaces, places, and their material and conceptual contours support the author-practitioner’s activities and offer insight into his worldview. This essay attempts to reconstruct something of the author-practitioner’s workshop, his itineraries in and beyond Toulouse, and his assumptions about environments of creative labor. The first half of the essay considers the space of the author-practitioner’s workshop, surveying the equipment, tools, and materials in his workspace and comparing them to the items commonly found in the workshops of contemporary French goldsmiths. The second half pivots to examine spaces beyond the workshop walls, examining the role of domestic spaces, the urban landscape, the countryside, and the wider world in the author-practitioner’s enterprise.

content.fullTitle: Making and Knowing Pedagogy
content.name: Making and Knowing Pedagogy
content.citeAs: Bilak, Donna. “Making and Knowing Pedagogy.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_305_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/n0x6-j545
content.abstract: In this essay, former Making and Knowing Postdoctoral Scholar Donna Bilak presents selected aspects of the pedagogy used by the Making and Knowing Project in its creation of Secrets of Craft and Nature. She discusses structures and principles of the Making and Knowing Project, and highlights two central pillars of the Making and Knowing Lab course: skill building and student reconstruction of the processes contained in Ms. Fr. 640. She underscores the importance of failure in pedagogy more generally, and provides examples of extensions of Making and Knowing pedagogy to a variety of other settings.

content.fullTitle: Avoiding 'Fleas' and Green Skies: Varnishes in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Avoiding 'Fleas' and Green Skies: Varnishes in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Bol, Marjolijn. “Avoiding 'Fleas' and Green Skies: Varnishes in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_306_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/zm3s-z238
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 contains more diverse and detailed instructions for the making of varnishes than any other sixteenth-century text. The varnish recipes in Ms. Fr. 640 are wide-ranging, from the protection of metals from corrosion, to the rain proofing of ephemeral festive decorations, to an ingredient in printer’s ink, to the imitation of other materials such as coral and gold, to the perhaps best known use of historical varnishes today, as coatings for easel paintings. This essay shows why the remarks and recipes in Ms. Fr. 640 about varnishes are of inestimable value in chronicling a previously unrecognized shift in the ingredients, preparation, uses, and aims of varnishes from the middle ages through the seventeenth century.

content.fullTitle: Working (with) the Corps: The Body of Sands, Colors, and Varnishes in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Corps in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Boulboullé, Jenny, and Maartje Stols-Witlox. “Working (with) the Corps: The Body of Sands, Colors, and Varnishes in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_307_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/jyms-a974
content.abstract: This essay traces the use of the term corps in Ms. Fr. 640, investigating its occurrence, meaning, and translation. While the term—which literally translates as “body”—seems straightforward to understand at first sight, close reading and comparison with contemporary sources and dictionaries reveals its complex web of meaning. Reconstructions underscore this fact and allow insight into the polysemic qualities of corps. Employing concepts from linguistics and anthropology, we argue that the author-practitioner employed corps as a rich linguistic strategy that allowed him to navigate the fields of practice and theory, to document or communicate aspects of artistic practice that would otherwise remain ineffable.

content.fullTitle: Arms and Armor in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Arms and Armor in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Tavares, Jonathan. “Arms and Armor in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_308_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/9rye-d152
content.abstract: BnF Ms. Fr. 640 offers a unique glimpse into the production and consumption of late sixteenth-century arms and armor. Most period sources, such as guild regulations, court documents, commissions, and inventories, provide only hints about the materials, techniques, cultural experience, and tacit knowledge that clearly once existed. A more vivid picture emerges from Ms. Fr. 640, which is discussed in this essay alongside surviving objects. The essay first addresses the craft of the furbisher or sword cutler discussed over four folios (fols. 94r–97r), and then the use and maintenance of firearms, their projectiles, and plate armor referenced in several entries. Ms. Fr. 640 reveals an industry reliant on a myriad of specialized sub-trades, where no single craftsmen can be credited with the finished product and sale of a sword, and a world in which plate armor and heavy cavalry were steadily giving way to advances and standardizations in firearms.

content.fullTitle: Artillery in 1590s France
content.name: Artillery in 1590s France
content.citeAs: Brioist, Pascal. “Artillery in 1590s France.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_309_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/p0j5-3395
content.abstract: BnF Ms. Fr. 640 offers a wealth of information on gunpowder weapons. During the wars of religion, gun technology was of the utmost importance, not only for those who produced these instruments of war, but also for those who made a profession of arms and had to ensure that these guns were safe to use. This essay examines the entries in Ms. Fr. 640 relating to weapons against the backdrop of this turbulent period in and around Toulouse, and compares them to other sources that treat gunpowder weaponry in sixteenth-century Europe.

content.fullTitle: Digital Development of the Digital Critical Edition of BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Digital Development of the Digital Critical Edition of BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Rosenkranz, Naomi, and Terry Catapano. “Digital Development of the Digital Critical Edition of BnF Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2025. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_310_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/fzw8-wn05
content.abstract: This essay examines the Making and Knowing Project's creation of a digital critical edition of BnF Ms. Fr. 640. The Project's unique methodology, combining historical research, material reconstruction, and digital scholarship, necessitated an iterative and collaborative approach to digital development. The challenges of working with a complex text like Ms. Fr. 640 are detailed, highlighting the need for flexibility and adaptability in both scholarly and technical workflows. The essay explores the evolution of the Project's digital tools and strategies. Throughout the process, the Project team navigated the tensions between scholarly thoroughness and practical constraints, emphasizing the importance of defining minimum viable products and setting clear priorities.

content.fullTitle: Le Ms. Fr. 640 et le contexte toulousain
content.name: Le contexte toulousain
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin, and Sarah Muñoz. “Le Ms. Fr. 640 et le contexte toulousain.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_312_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/4nre-vd21
content.abstract: L’appartenance du Ms. Fr. 640 à la collection Béthune de la Bibliothèque nationale de France et le fait que les trois maîtres artisans mentionnés sur la première page du manuscrit aient vécu à Paris ont d’abord incité à mener des recherches en direction du contexte parisien. Plusieurs noms de personnes, de lieux et d’autres indications contenus dans le manuscrit indiquent cependant que ce dernier fut écrit par un homme familier du Languedoc, ayant probablement vécu à Toulouse à la fin du XVIe siècle. À travers l’analyse de l’activité des artilleurs, des fondeurs, des peintres et des orfèvres toulousains, cet essai vise à mieux comprendre le contexte politique, économique et artistique dans lequel l’auteur-praticien du Ms. Fr. 640 rédigea ce recueil. Plusieurs recettes du manuscrit et les centres d’intérêt dont témoigne l’auteur-praticien font écho à l’activité, à l’ambition et aux collaborations des artisans les plus importants de la capitale languedocienne, tels que les frères Masse, orfèvres, et Barthélémy Fraysse, fondeur à l’Arsenal. For the English version of this essay, see https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_336_ie_19.

content.fullTitle: Raymond Masse: un marchand-orfèvre dans l’environnement de l’auteur-praticien
content.name: Raymond Masse, marchand-orfèvre
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin. “Raymond Masse: un marchand-orfèvre dans l’environnement de l’auteur-praticien.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_313_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/a0gv-p550
content.abstract: Tout au long de l’époque moderne, Toulouse fut une cité attractive pour les orfèvres. L’auteur-praticien du Ms. Fr. 640, qui possédait une forge d’orfèvre (fol. 12v) et fit de multiples références à l’orfèvrerie dans les recettes de son manuscrit, a probablement été au contact de plusieurs maîtres toulousains. C’est sans doute le cas du marchand-orfèvre Raymond Masse, actif à Toulouse de 1585 à 1631, dont l’activité, les collaborations et les relations locales et internationales offrent de nombreuses similitudes avec les préoccupations de l’auteur-praticien et éclairent plusieurs mentions du manuscrit. For the English version of this essay, see https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_338_ie_19.

content.fullTitle: Adaptation à un contexte de guerre et aux enjeux économiques de la seconde moitié du XVIe siècle: les trajectoires professionnelles de Dominique Bertin et Hélie Bachelier
content.name: Dominique Bertin et Hélie Bachelier
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin. “Adaptation à un contexte de guerre et aux enjeux économiques de la seconde moitié du XVIe siècle: les trajectoires professionnelles de Dominique Bertin et Hélie Bachelier.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_314_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/pwre-5t39
content.abstract: L’affaiblissement de l’autorité royale ainsi que les guerres de religion troublèrent le royaume de France de 1562 à 1598. Pour autant, cette période ne fut pas synonyme d’une décadence artistique comme les historiens et les historiens de l’art l’ont démontré depuis la fin du 20e siècle. Les trajectoires professionnelles des artisans toulousains, comme celles de Dominique Bertin et d’Hélie Bachelier, éclairent le contexte de rédaction du manuscrit Fr. 640. Elles permettent de comprendre comment leur polyvalence se met au service du Politique et rendent évident les intérêts économique et militaire de leurs savoir-faire. For the English version of this essay, see https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_339_ie_19.

content.fullTitle: A Fragmentary Goldsmithing Manuscript from Seventeenth-Century Toulouse
content.name: Toulouse Goldsmithing Manuscript
content.citeAs: Muñoz, Sarah. “A Fragmentary Goldsmithing Manuscript from Seventeenth-Century Toulouse.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_315_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/7hbr-by50
content.abstract: The Archives municipales of Toulouse hold an unpublished fragment of an anonymous seventeenth-century manuscript that compiles goldsmiths’ statutes, recipes from a goldsmithing workshop, and knowledge on stones and minerals. As part of the Mint’s collection, it raises questions related primarily to its source and use. Through analysis of the manuscript’s eight folios, this essay compares it with Ms. Fr. 640. In contrast to Ms. Fr. 640’s many recipes, this document shows a more heterogeneous character, however, some of its recipes, as well as its lively interest in gemstones, display surprising similarities with Ms. Fr. 640.

content.fullTitle: Le Ms. Fr. 640 et la collection Béthune
content.name: Le Ms. Fr. 640 et la collection Béthune
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin. “Le Ms. Fr. 640 et la collection Béthune.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_316_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/dkrp-q111
content.abstract: L’étude de la collection Béthune, qui fut intégrée dans la bibliothèque royale en 1662, révèle non seulement les inclinations du bibliophile et diplomate Philippe de Béthune (1561–1649), le frère de Sully, mais permet également d’évaluer la place du Ms. Fr. 640 dans cette collection. Plus largement, cette analyse tente de situer cet ouvrage dans le contexte intellectuel et scientifique de la fin du 16e siècle et de la première moitié du 17e siècle. For the English version of this essay, see https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_337_ie_19.

content.fullTitle: Barthélémy Fraysse and the Author-Practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Barthélémy Fraysse and the Author-Practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Muñoz, Sarah. “Barthélémy Fraysse and the Author-Practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_317_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/k2a3-qm96
content.abstract: Among the metal founders of Toulouse, Barthélémy Fraysse stands out for his varied activities and his links to significant Toulouse individuals, such as the Poncet family, who is mentioned in Ms. Fr. 640. Original research carried out for this essay in the “Comptes du trésorier” and the “Pièces à l’appui des comptes” of the Archives municipales of Toulouse reveal that Fraysse frequently received payments from the municipality of Toulouse between 1570 and 1590. Further documents show that his activity continued through 1620. He was successively cannon maker, founder, founder of artillery, and gunner. Between 1570 and 1590, several of his activities can be compared to the subjects of multiple entries in BnF Ms. Fr. 640.

content.fullTitle: Artisans of Toulouse
content.name: Artisans of Toulouse
content.citeAs: Muñoz, Sarah, and Colin Debuiche. “Artisans of Toulouse.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_332_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/2t4p-ca59
content.abstract: Many artisans worked in Toulouse in the years during which Ms. Fr. 640 was likely written, and their names can be found among the archives of Toulouse, especially the “Comptes du trésorier,” the “Pièces à l’appui des comptes,” the registers of the 1571 cadastre in the Archives Municipales of Toulouse, as well as the minutes of notaries in the Archives Départementales de la Haute-Garonne. The activities and handwriting of these goldsmiths, founders, artisans working for the Arsenal and the Mint of Toulouse, and other guild artisans were examined, as these could have been professionals who worked alongside the author-practitioner or even the author-practitioner himself. A list of artisans classified by profession, along with information on their documented dates, location in the city (when known), proximity to notaries, and handwriting is provided, which demonstrates that in handwriting, at least, the author-practitioner was not represented among them.

content.fullTitle: Turning Turtle: The Process of Translating BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: The Process of Translating Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Dyon, Soersha, and Heather Wacha. “Turning Turtle: The Process of Translating BnF Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_318_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/1pw7-ax09
content.abstract: By focusing on the translation of the entries on molding and casting turtles from life in BnF Ms. Fr. 640, this essay seeks to underscore and bring to light the chronology, choices, and processes behind the Project’s translation of the manuscript. Our translation serves two main goals: to accurately represent the author-practitioner’s intentions and voice, as unhindered as possible by twenty-first-century assumptions, and to provide a window onto the vivid world described in the manuscript.

content.fullTitle: Court Workshops and Statecraft as Sites for Artisanal Knowledge Production and Exchange
content.name: Court Workshops and Statecraft
content.citeAs: Hermens, Erma. "Court Workshops and Statecraft as Sites for Artisanal Knowledge Production and Exchange.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_319_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/0pkq-rb97
content.abstract: In the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries, various European courts established artisanal workshop clusters which contained a wide range of professions for producing objects ranging from the temporary and ephemeral to the durable and valuable, from modest household items to serve the court to highly sophisticated artifacts that demonstrated skilled craftsmanship, technical innovation, and material preciousness. These workshops were sites for the exchange of techniques, skills, and knowledge, as well as, frequently, for creating a “brand” identity for the ruler or court. Understanding the political and economic aspects of the multifaceted contexts, in which artifacts were produced for the court’s collections, galleries, and palaces as well as for political exchange of gifts, can inform us about the motivation of the author-practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640 in writing and compiling his text.

content.fullTitle: "Everything Depends Upon the Trial (Le tout gist à l’essay)": Four Manuscripts Between the Recipe and the Experimental Essay
content.name: Four Manuscripts between the Recipe and the Experimental Essay
content.citeAs: Keller, Vera. “‘Everything Depends Upon the Trial (Le tout gist à l’essay)’: Four Manuscripts Between the Recipe and the Experimental Essay.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_320_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/vj69-8h20
content.abstract: A comparison between four manuscripts demonstrates an evolution from the genre of the recipe to the experimental essay. As a notion of general experience slowly transformed into the practice of experimentation at a particular time and place, how-to accounts became increasingly historicized and personalized. In contrast to widespread narratives depicting modern science as a thinning of previously thick, embodied knowledge, this evolution demonstrates knowledge thickening, becoming more personalized and explicit both about material experience and symbolic interpretation. This is apparent in the case of Ms. Fr. 640, in the frequent use of the first-person voice, especially at points in which the author-practitioner was most actively engaged in speculating about and experimenting with new techniques.This long-term evolution of the experimental essay situates the epistemology of making and knowing in relation to previous long-term accounts concerning the scientific method. Previously, the experimental essay has been associated with Restoration experimental philosophy, as it developed out of the works of Sir Francis Bacon. In such accounts, the experimental essay serves as the ideal expression of a particular epistemology. This essay backdates the experimental essay and demonstrates its slow emergence from the genre of the recipe. Showing the experimental essay’s connection with prior genres also suggests experimental philosophy’s connection with previous epistemologies. Neither the experimental essay nor experimental philosophy emerged fully formed in the works of Bacon and his followers. On the slow course of development that produced them, we can situate Ms. Fr. 640 at an important stage of the personalization and historicization of experiment.

content.fullTitle: An Active Form of Education: The Boutique and the Tablet of Cebes
content.name: An Active Form of Education
content.citeAs: Keller, Vera. “An Active Form of Education: The Boutique and the Tablet of Cebes.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_330_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/dy3g-xm85
content.abstract: This essay explores how the author-practitioner’s vision of making and knowing compares to formal ideas of education in the period.

content.fullTitle: Ancient and Modern Things in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Ancient and Modern Things in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Keller, Vera. “Ancient and Modern Things in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_331_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/m255-ps74
content.abstract: The recovery of the ancient Greco-Roman world was a defining feature of what we call the “Renaissance.” This essay explores how the author-practitioner situated his craft techniques as part of a larger movement for recovering antiquity.

content.fullTitle: Ms. Fr. 640 in the World of Pigments in Sixteenth-Century Europe
content.name: Ms. Fr. 640 in the World of Pigments in Sixteenth-Century Europe
content.citeAs: Kirby, Jo, and Marika Spring. “Ms. Fr. 640 in the World of Pigments in Sixteenth-Century Europe.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_321_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/vsrt-8r31
content.abstract: The discussion of painting in Ms. Fr. 640 forms a relatively small proportion of its content, but one that is significant. In most sixteenth-century compilations and “secrets” books, discussion of painting is largely limited to recipes for materials, often copied from elsewhere. Some, derived from earlier sources for manuscript illumination, describe how to paint particular details such as faces and hair of young people, or animals and birds. Ms. Fr. 640’s author-practitioner describes aspects of Flemish painting practice fairly accurately, perhaps from information received or from observation, and also mentions details of Italian painting practice, relating to painting faces. His account of materials treats their behavior in oil paint, rather than the list and description of individual pigments commonly found in other texts. This emphasis on practical painting in oil for a variety of purposes, including painting decorative metalwork and glass, is unusual in sources of this date, not found in such detail until the seventeenth century. The use of cristallin glass as a drier is described and, more interestingly, its additional ability to give translucency to opaque paint. The attention paid to the blue glass pigment smalt and its properties is unusual: it indicates some difficulties associated with its use, not discussed in other contemporary sources. Other blues, also green, red, yellow, white and black pigments are mentioned, but the author-practitioner’s particular interest is in translucency, which may relate to his interest in cast metalwork.

content.fullTitle: Methodologies for Making and Knowing: Reconstructions for Historical Research
content.name: Methodologies for Making and Knowing
content.citeAs: Klein, Joel. “Methodologies for Making and Knowing: Reconstructions for Historical Research.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_322_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/s7f5-5h76
content.abstract: This essay summarizes some recent historiography that has featured historical reconstructions, and discusses the Making and Knowing Project’s particular methodologies for reconstructing the practices, techniques, and technologies documented in Ms. Fr. 640. Reconstruction has been successfully employed by historians of science, art historians, conservators, experimental archaeologists, and a variety of other groups who each used a particular methodology for addressing questions about history. In the graduate seminars of the Making and Knowing Laboratory, students were guided through several skill-building activities before devising a research project of their own. Research in the laboratory emphasized a careful understanding of historical materials, a focus on the process rather than the outcome of reconstructions, and a synergistic relationship between textual research and laboratory work. I argue that our experimental method can best be understood as exploratory experimentation. Likewise, while the methods developed were specific to reconstruction of entries in Ms. Fr. 640, there are many other applications across a broad spectrum of historical research and pedagogy.

content.fullTitle: Collectors and Practitioners of Technical Knowledge: A Comparison of Wolfgang Sedelius and the Author-Practitioner of BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Collectors and Practitioners of Technical Knowledge
content.citeAs: Oltrogge, Doris. “Collectors and Practitioners of Technical Knowledge: A Comparison of Wolfgang Sedelius and the Author-Practitioner of BnF Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_323_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/j087-ke63
content.abstract: Recipe collections are the major literary genre for the transmission of technical knowledge from Antiquity through the early modern period. Their flexibility allowed for the adaptation to a number of different uses in various contexts, from specialized workshop notebooks to encyclopedic compendia. This essay compares the author-practitioner of BnF Ms. Fr. 640 with a slightly older South German counterpart, Wolfgang Sedelius (1491/92–1562). As a monk and court preacher, Sedelius comes from a different social and intellectual milieu than the anonymous French author-practitioner. Although first and foremost a theologian, he was also broadly interested in mathematics, mechanics, artisanal techniques, chemistry, and medicine. His three surviving recipe collections, compiled over a period of about thirty years, document the personal approach of a scholar interested in a variety of technical and scientific fields. In his later manuscripts Sedelius interviewed and observed expert practitioners and personally experimented himself—approaches similar to that of the author-practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640, although their individual interests and expertises differ.

content.fullTitle: Ingenious Materials: Salts as Material Metaphor
content.name: Ingenious Materials: Salts as Material Metaphor
content.citeAs: Oosterhoff, Richard. “Ingenious Materials: Salts as Material Metaphor.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_324_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/4vf4-2867
content.abstract: Like blood and gold, salt was a material that brimmed with meaning in late medieval and early modern Europe. As a material metaphor, salt became a way to think about the innate generativity and fertility of nature for authors such as Bernard Palissy or Joseph Du Chesne. Yet I show that the analogy between human wit and nature’s creative power remained absent from Ms. Fr. 640. Here then is the puzzle. If any material in this manuscript book of recipes were a material metaphor, surely it would be salts. Yet ingenuity does not overtly define the manifold roles of salts in Ms. Fr. 640. This striking difference with other books of secrets gives us an analytical thread to pull. How do we get from the experience of salts, as it surfaces in many recipes of the manuscript, to the elaborate ingenuity of salt in contemporary authors such as Palissy or Du Chesne? By contrasting Ms. Fr. 640 with books of secrets that make more of salts, we can probe more finely into how the experience of materials relates to textual tradition in shaping this genre.

content.fullTitle: Daily Life and Material Culture in Early Modern Europe
content.name: Daily Life and Material Culture in Early Modern Europe
content.citeAs: Pitman, Sophie. “Daily Life and Material Culture in Early Modern Europe.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_325_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/ebsm-h148
content.abstract: This essay explores what we can learn about daily life in early modern France through a close reading of BnF Ms. Fr. 640. Reading across instructions, observations, and marginal illustrations, it reveals everyday practices, local proverbs, beliefs, and material culture, contributing to our understanding of the cultural, physical, conceptual, and material environment of early modern Europe.

content.fullTitle: Making Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Making Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Smith, Marc. “Making Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_326_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/1wmr-2t14
content.abstract: A close physical and visual examination of Ms. Fr. 640, in terms of codicology (material structure) and paleography (handwriting), can tell us much about how it was created and handed down to its present location, and thus allows us to better understand its contents. Contrary to the first impression it might give the reader of a smoothly coherent whole written from front to back cover, it is instead the result of complex intellectual and technical movement back and forth between experimenting and writing, both at the time of its composition and later when it became embalmed as a valuable library item, right down to the present day in its most recent avatar as a digital facsimile, edition, and translation.

content.fullTitle: The Drawings in BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: The Drawings in BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Fransen, Sietske. “The Drawings in BnF Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2024. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_327_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/7cr7-5a61
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 is part of an early modern European note-taking tradition which included sketches and drawings as part of a larger written text. Ms. Fr. 640’s author-practitioner not only wrote his text, he also drew images in his manuscript. This essay considers several questions about these images: How can we characterize the images? What was the aim of the illustrations, how do they relate to the texts and practices captured by the author-practitioner, and how do they compare to other late sixteenth-century illustrated manuscripts and printed texts? And, can the images provide insights into the manuscript and its maker that the text on its own cannot?

content.fullTitle: The Physical Construction of Ms. Fr. 640
