content.name: The Physical Construction of Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Hagadorn, Alexis. “The Physical Construction of Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_328_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/ar0p-h544
content.abstract: Important clues about manuscripts can be inferred through analysis of their bindings. This essay not only examines Ms. Fr. 640’s current binding, but also attempts to determine its original construction and appearance by comparing it with other French manuscripts available in the collections of Columbia University Libraries, and by reconstructing a model of its binding and gatherings using a textblock made of “watermarked” paper following Marc Smith’s collation.

content.fullTitle: Making the Edition of Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Making the Edition
content.citeAs: Smith, Pamela H. “Making the Edition of Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_329_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/zdaf-cv31
content.abstract: This essay describes the Making and Knowing Project’s creation of the Digital Critical Edition of Ms. Fr. 640 through interdisciplinary pedagogy and research. It elaborates the various components of the Project, including Text Workshops, Laboratory and Digital Seminars, institutional collaborations, and digital design and development. The potentials and pitfalls of the method of historical reconstruction in a laboratory are discussed, and an introductory survey of insights gained through the student research in texts, objects, and hands-on laboratory work is provided.

content.fullTitle: Natural Philosophy and Chemistry in Manuscripts of the Béthune Collection
content.name: Natural Philosophy and Chemistry in the Béthune Collection
content.citeAs: Muñoz, Sarah. “Natural Philosophy and Chemistry in Manuscripts of the Béthune Collection.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_333_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/pqzj-gv61
content.abstract: This essay explores a set of seventy-five manuscripts that belonged to Philippe de Béthune, now in the Bibliothèque nationale de France, containing encyclopedic knowledge and writings on natural philosophy and alchemy (Ms. Fr. 2513-2589). The themes reflected in these manuscripts give insight into Philippe de Béthune’s interests and help situate Ms. Fr. 640 within them. Although some of these manuscripts touch on similar themes to Ms. Fr. 640, and others treat observations about materials and information related to artisanal techniques, none display the compilation of practical recipes that characterizes Ms. Fr. 640.

content.fullTitle: Tutor or Student? An Expert Maker Perspective
content.name: An Expert Maker Perspective
content.citeAs: Beentjes, Tonny. “Tutor or Student? An Expert Maker Perspective.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_334_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/rzm3-dt19
content.abstract: Each semester, the Making and Knowing Project invited an Expert Maker to spend two weeks with the Craft and Science course in order to introduce students to necessary skills for their lab work. Silversmith and conservator, Tonny Beentjes (Head of the Metals Conservation Programme, University of Amsterdam) joined the Project in Fall 2014. He led the students in sand molding in frames, following Ms. Fr. 640, fol. 118v. The students then took their molds to be cast in the Ubaldo Vitali Studio. In this essay, Tonny discusses his experience as an Expert Maker and the need to find a via media between his training in contemporary practices and the pursuit of historical reconstructions with novice students.

content.fullTitle: Ma<r>king and Knowing: Encoding BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Encoding BnF Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Camps, Celine, and Margot Lyautey. “Ma<r>king and Knowing: Encoding BnF Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_335_ie_19. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.7916/cjhd-wh90
content.abstract: This essay reflects on the process of marking up Ms. Fr. 640. While it is tempting to think of encoding as a straightforward process, this essay argues that encoding Ms. Fr. 640 was more than a matter of simply reading a text, identifying categories, and implementing tags. Rather, it was a complex and messy process which required close reading, continuous reflection and alteration, collective expertise, and collaboration between humanists and computers. This essay highlights the flexible, volatile, and non-finite nature of markup, and it illustrates that encoding was not a linear process, but rather was characterized by moving back and forth between pages, constantly implementing new and correcting old markup in an attempt to adhere to new decisions and safeguard consistency. Finally, it shows how solutions to markup problems were frequently sought by considering a user’s perspective. We conclude that encoding Ms. Fr. 640 not only required knowledge but also produced it.

content.fullTitle: Ms. Fr. 640: The Toulouse Context
content.name: The Toulouse Context
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin, and Sarah Muñoz. “Ms. Fr. 640: The Toulouse Context,” translated by Philippe Barré and Christine Julliot de la Morandière. In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_336_ie_19. DOI:
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 belongs to the Béthune collection in the Bibliothèque nationale de France, and the names of three master artisans living in Paris are mentioned on the first page, thus appearing to connect the text to a Parisian context. Several personal and place names and other clues in the manuscript indicate, however, that it was written by an individual familiar with the Languedoc who probably lived in Toulouse at the end of the sixteenth century. This essay discusses the activity of Toulouse’s gunners, founders, painters, and goldsmiths to shed light on the political, economic, and artistic context in which the author-practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640 wrote. Several entries in the manuscript and the interests of its author-practitioner echo the activities, collaborations, and ambitions of the most prominent craftsmen of the Languedoc capital, such as the goldsmith Masse brothers and the Arsenal metal founder Barthélémy Fraysse. Cliquez ici pour la version française: https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_312_ie_19.

content.fullTitle: Ms. Fr. 640 and the Béthune Collection
content.name: Ms. Fr. 640 and the Béthune Collection
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin. “Ms. Fr. 640 and the Béthune Collection,” translated by Christine Julliot de la Morandière and Philippe Barré. In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_337_ie_19. DOI:
content.abstract: Studying the Béthune collection, which was integrated into the royal library in 1662, not only reveals the inclinations of diplomat and bibliophile Philippe de Béthune (1561–1649), the Duke of Sully’s brother, but also enables us to evaluate the place of Ms. Fr. 640 within this collection. More broadly, this analysis attempts to place this work in the intellectual and cultural context of late sixteenth- and early seventeenth-century France. Cliquez ici pour la version française: https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_316_ie_19.

content.fullTitle:
Raymond Masse: Merchant-Goldsmith in the Environment of
the Author-Practitioner
content.name: Raymond Masse: Merchant-Goldsmith
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin. “Raymond Masse: Merchant-Goldsmith in the Environment of the Author-Practitioner,” translated by Philippe Barré and Christine Julliot de la Morandière. In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_338_ie_19. DOI:
content.abstract: Toulouse has long been an attractive city for goldsmiths. The author-practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640, who owned a goldsmith's forge (fol. 12v) and made multiple references to goldsmithing in the entries of his manuscript, was probably in contact with several masters from Toulouse. This profile resembles that of the merchant and goldsmith Raymond Masse. Active in Toulouse from 1585 to 1631, Masse’s activity, collaborations and relationships, both on a local and international level, bear many similarities with the concerns of the author-practitioner and shed light on several passages of the manuscript. Cliquez ici pour la version française: https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_313_ie_19

content.fullTitle: War and Economy in Late Sixteenth-Century Languedoc: Dominique Bertin and Hélie Bachelier
content.name: Dominique Bertin and Hélie Bachelier
content.citeAs: Debuiche, Colin. “War and Economy in Late Sixteenth-Century Languedoc: Dominique Bertin and Hélie Bachelier,” translated by Christine Julliot de la Morandière and Philippe Barré. In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_339_ie_19. DOI:
content.abstract: The erosion of royal authority and the wars of religion disrupted the kingdom of France from 1562 to 1598. However, as scholars have demonstrated recently, this troubled history did not translate into artistic decay. The professional trajectories of artisans from Toulouse, such as Dominique Bertin and Hélie Bachelier, shed light on the context in which Ms. Fr. 640 was written. It allows us to understand how these artisans put their versatile talents at the service of political power, revealing the economic and military benefits of their know-how. Cliquez ici pour la version française: https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_314_ie_19.

content.fullTitle: Mr. Toad’s Wild Ride: From Bestiary to Shop Manual
content.name: From Bestiary to Shop Manual
content.citeAs: Demeter, Béla. “Mr. Toad’s Wild Ride: From Bestiary to Shop Manual.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_500_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/3dck-4657
content.abstract: In sixteenth-century Europe, animals often served as allegorical embodiments of moral principles, while toads and vipers, in particular, were valued primarily for their putative medicinal value. In a marked departure from these conventions, the author-practitioner records his thoughts on capturing, restraining, maintaining, and killing these animals. Although not a natural historian by vocation, in the course of casting amphibians and reptiles from life into objects of art, he amassed considerable knowledge of the habits and characteristics of this often spurned class of animals, especially of vipers. The few people who dealt with these animals—including other artisans, viper catchers, and apothecaries—did not record their observations. In this essay, I survey the author-practitioner’s forays into herpetological husbandry, capture techniques, and methods of euthanasia. I compare these observations with the few other accounts from the time, which do not contain the detail or accuracy found in Ms. Fr. 640.

content.fullTitle: In Pursuit of Magic
content.name: In Pursuit of Magic
content.citeAs: Lacey, Andrew, and Siân Lewis. “In Pursuit of Magic.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_501_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/79dn-mn48
content.abstract: Andrew Lacey and Siân Lewis spent two weeks in spring 2015 with the Making and Knowing Project leading students in lifecasting experiments. In their essay, they provide an account of Lacey’s experimentation and analysis of lifecasting techniques in advance of the Making and Knowing Residency, the real-time x-ray videos of metal casting they produced, and the whirlwind of Making and Knowing Lab activity in spring 2015.

content.fullTitle: Animals Dried in an Oven
content.name: Animals Dried in an Oven
content.citeAs: Anantharaman, Divya, and Pamela H. Smith. “Animals Dried in an Oven.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_502_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/c46b-1h45
content.abstract: Divya Anantharaman came to the Making and Knowing Laboratory in fall 2016 as Expert Maker in residence, where she reconstructed entries from Ms. Fr. 640, including “Animals dried in an oven” on fol. 130r, for preserving animals intended to be displayed as lifelike specimens. This essay records her responses to the early modern methods she encountered in Ms. Fr. 640 and the reconstruction she and the Making and Knowing Team undertook.

content.fullTitle: Toulouse Sand
content.name: Toulouse Sand
content.citeAs: Julien, Pascal, and Pamela H. Smith. “Toulouse Sand.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_503_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/49ev-6422
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 contains numerous references to Languedoc and Toulouse. The most numerous entries referring to Toulouse by name are about an excellent sand which can be gathered from the Toulouse environs and used to make molds for metal casting. These entries are particularly interesting for their account of firsthand experience and their observations about the properties of natural and artificial sands. They are detailed enough that they can be followed to locate and gather Toulouse sand suitable for making molds for metal casting. This essay recounts the search for Toulouse sand and the reconstructions made with it in the Making and Knowing Lab.

content.fullTitle: Molding, Modeling, and Repairing: Lifecast Snakes Modeled in Black Wax
content.name: Molding, Modeling, and Repairing
content.citeAs: Noirot, Fabien. “Molding, Modeling, and Repairing: Lifecast Snakes Modeled in Black Wax.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_504_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/8je7-1124
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 contains several entries for producing casts through a process of molding and casting in successive molds. One of these is “Cast of wax to represent an animal that one has not got” (fols. 139v–140v). This entry presupposes that the practitioner has already lifecast a natural snake in a straight shape in a plaster mold. This plaster mold is poured with a special black wax which can be bent into the shape of an undulating snake. This black wax snake then forms the model for a “sand” mold (plaster and refractory materials), in which metal is cast. On the basis of this and other related entries, this essay recounts a reconstruction of the plaster molding and wax bending processes, and compares the resulting cast to an extant sixteenth-century cast bronze snake that is a combination of lifecasting and “repair,” or modeling.

content.fullTitle: Making Gold Run for Casting
content.name: Making Gold Run for Casting
content.citeAs: Boyd, Emily, Jef Palframan, and Pamela H. Smith. “Making Gold Run for Casting.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_505_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/39qh-ak44
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 contains several entries for making metals “run.” Fluidly running metals are essential in casting. These entries, including “Making gold run for casting” on fol. 106r, are among the most carefully observed and most laboriously written sections in Ms. Fr. 640. Like lifecasting and gem making entries in other parts of the manuscript, they appear to have been at the heart of the author-practitioner’s interests and his firsthand experimentation.

content.fullTitle: Molding with Cuttlefish Bone
content.name: Molding with Cuttlefish Bone
content.citeAs: Boyd, Emily, Jef Palframan, and Pamela H. Smith. “Molding with Cuttlefish Bone.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_506_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/1dc2-rn58
content.abstract: Several entries mention cuttlefish bone in Ms. Fr. 640: some use the powder of cuttlefish bones as a method of erasing (fol. 15v), others employ calcined cuttlefish powder as a sand for making molds (fol. 49r), but most of these entries make use of the bone as a rapidly-produced mold into which metals are cast, including fols. 91r–v and 145r–v. These entries provide a wealth of information on preparing the bones for molding, impressing models into them, and, finally, casting metals into them. They also contain descriptions of techniques by which an artisan could test the temperature of molten metal before casting. These entries particularly highlight the sensory and bodily knowledge needed by an artisan. We learned through experience the value of this knowledge in the course of our reconstructions.

content.fullTitle: For Making Very Beautiful Color of Gold
content.name: For Making Very Beautiful Color of Gold
content.citeAs: Palframan, Jef, and Emily Boyd. “For Making Very Beautiful Color of Gold.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_507_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/s784-zk74
content.abstract: Among the many recipes in Ms. Fr. 640 for making gold color, an unusual one entitled “For making very beautiful color of gold & of little expense,” on fol. 76v calls for mixing ground orange peel with sulfur. The reconstruction of this recipe did not result in “a very beautiful color,” but more experimentation is necessary.

content.fullTitle: Lifecasting in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Lifecasting in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: Smith, Pamela H. “Lifecasting in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_511_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/ym8m-r917
content.abstract: Over a third of Ms. Fr. 640 is devoted to mold making and metal casting, and, among these long and detailed entries are the accounts of many first hand trials of lifecasting. It is clear that lifecasting was a major preoccupation (perhaps the major preoccupation) of the author-practitioner. The folios pertaining to it contain the longest and most densely written entries, with numerous marginal additions, copious recounting of first hand experience, and many remarkable sketches, making them among the most complicated but rewarding for the modern reader-practitioner to decipher.

content.fullTitle: Varied and Transmuted Wine
content.name: Varied and Transmuted Wine
content.citeAs: Mukherjee, Sayantani. “Varied and Transmuted Wine.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_512_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/6b6c-vt11
content.abstract: Ms. Fr. 640 contains an entry on fol. 43v for “Varied and Transmuted Wine.” This recipe contains no wine, but transmutes red “wine” into white. Is this entry a test for detecting adulteration in wines? Or is it a deceptive trick?

content.fullTitle: Thinking and Experiencing Techne
content.name: Thinking and Experiencing Techne
content.citeAs: Victoria and Albert Museum-Royal College of Art Students. “Thinking and Experiencing Techne.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_513_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/3m2d-gh51
content.abstract: Since Spring 2015, the Making and Knowing Project’s laboratory seminar and the Victoria and Albert Museum/Royal College of Art Postgraduate Programme in the History of Design have collaborated on researching and reconstructing Ms. Fr. 640’s recipes. Students and team members have worked together on counterfeit coral, varnishes, and the blue pigment the author-practitioner calls “azur.”

content.fullTitle: Two Author-Practitioners in Dialogue across Time
content.name: Two Author-Practitioners in Dialogue across Time
content.citeAs: Price, Michael. “Two Author-Practitioners in Dialogue across Time.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_514_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/x5kc-kj05
content.abstract: Artist Michael Price has dedicated his career to understanding the materials and techniques of early modern painters through historical painting recipes, technical analysis and conservation literature, and experiments using natural pigments and traditionally prepared binding mediums. His experience publishing his research findings and making processes position him as an ideal interlocutor for the author-practitioner of Ms. Fr. 640. In this essay, Price surveys the manuscript’s entries on the topics of painting and varnish, offering insights from his own practice and arguing that the author-practitioner’s knowledge of the painter’s craft is largely second hand.

content.fullTitle: Making Colored Wood in Ms. Fr. 640
content.name: Making Colored Wood in Ms. Fr. 640
content.citeAs: McClure, David. “Making Colored Wood in Ms. Fr. 640.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_515_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/atee-xn84
content.abstract: Five entries on fol. 76r of Ms. Fr. 640 offer instructions for dyeing wood, without detailing the type of wood in question or the use to which the dyed wood is to be put. These entries are part of a larger cluster on the coloring of wood, bone, and horn that spans fols. 73r to 79r. This essay reconstructs the recipes for dyeing wood red and green, and it situates them in the context of wood inlay and marquetry, decorative techniques in vogue in early modern Europe.

content.fullTitle: “Perspective is Very Difficult”: Practical and Impractical Tools for the Painter
content.name: “Perspective is Very Difficult”
content.citeAs: Wang, Xinguo, Ariane van Buren, and Tianna Helena Uchacz, “'Perspective is Very Difficult': Practical and Impractical Tools for the Painter.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_516_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/091b-1c16
content.abstract: The entry “Perspective” on fol. 62v describes and depicts practical tools to help an artist construct the underdrawing for an oil painting according to the rules of linear perspective, including a ruler for laying down orthogonals that converge at a single vanishing point. The author-practitioner describes two different designs for this tool and even provides an illustration of one of them. However, this drawing, when reconstructed, yields a sub-optimal result. It is unclear whether the author-practitioner had first-hand knowledge of such a tool, invented it as he wrote without thinking through the design, or exaggerated certain features in his drawing that, when reproduced as depicted, made the tool problematic to use.

content.fullTitle: Varnishes in the Rain
content.name: Varnishes in the Rain
content.citeAs: Rosenkranz, Naomi, and Tianna Helena Uchacz. “Varnishes in the Rain.” In Secrets of Craft and Nature in Renaissance France. A Digital Critical Edition and English Translation of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, edited by Making and Knowing Project, Pamela H. Smith, Naomi Rosenkranz, Tianna Helena Uchacz, Tillmann Taape, Clément Godbarge, Sophie Pitman, Jenny Boulboullé, Joel Klein, Donna Bilak, Marc Smith, and Terry Catapano. New York: Making and Knowing Project, 2020. https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_517_ad_20. DOI: https://doi.org/10.7916/2kka-4d12
content.abstract: In the entry “Varnish resistant to water” on fol. 31r of BnF Ms. Fr. 640, the author-practitioner describes what conservators today recognize as two types of varnish: spirit-based and oil-based. Moreover, he claims that the former resist the rain while latter do not. An experiment was designed to test these claims, informed by previous canvas preparation and varnish making experiments in the Making and Knowing lab. A test canvas, painted with oil paints and covered with four varnishes arranged side by side, was exposed to the elements May 30–Oct 18, 2018, and then compared to a control version kept indoors. Preliminary results suggest that the spirit varnishes are indeed better able to withstand rain than their oil-based counterparts; however, an unvarnished strip of the test canvas faired nearly as well as the spirit varnish, suggesting that the “Varnish resistant to water” may not have been intended to cover oil paint but another medium—perhaps distemper. Additional experiments are needed.
